column31: I just sat down with students and showed them how to put their essays into chatgpt and get feedback. It was a game- changer. Think about it-chatgpt is way more efficient, less subjective, and it doesn't get tired after reading 10 essays in a row. Also, I don't think the students get as offended when it criticizes them because it's not personal. I wouldn't rely on it for a final grade, but to give feedback, it's really quite extraordinary, and I think it will go a long way towards helping students improve as writers. Imagine having students submit 3-4 drafts instead of just the one that takes forever to comment on. Anyways, the prompt was: "give me specific feedback on how to improve my literary essay, focusing on organization, analysis, and tone. Don't rewrite it for me." And then paste in the essay.

I'm a Computing Lecturer at college in the UK. I wanted to share my experience and thoughts in these early days of setting tasks/assignments where students can use AI in the classroom. I'm beginning to see how to use AI to a great advantage for students to learn, not just skills in my subject area but for them to learn basic skills in creativity and communication. *I'm not an English teacher but there could be room for collaborative work.* I get the students to use ChatGPT to create web based on a design that they've created based on a given scenario to a problem. They ask ChatGPT to create code by describing their design (or parts of). I'm seeing that AI then produces the code to a very reasonable standard. However, it may not fully represent what is asked or has bugs in code. The student needs to analyse the output and refine their input and fix bugs. First of all, AI allows a faster and efficient way to write realistic code, but secondly the quality AI produces requires more structured requests/writing that are real world problems they would face in the work place. In other words, if the student struggles to give a structured and detailed description it will not give them everything they need or potentially lower quality solution. On the other hand, if they give it a really good detail they get a more fitting solution and they will still need to fix bugs. Of course, AI will improve over time, but I guess we would need to create more challenging scenarios. Moreover, this is the future of the workplace for employees where they analyse the output of AI. This is also why jobs will not necessarily be redundant because industury will alway push the technology to its limits. Thus subsequent generations will just need to be better at applying and correcting AI output. The following lessons are work-in-progress (or at least I've havent tested end to end) that include steps to creating a solution using ChatGPT for higher education students (given the request and responses I gave and received). https://github.com/drussell1974/web2py_bootstrap_application/blob/dev/projects/ats_veterinarian_booking_system/LESSON_1.md * I created the web2py application so, for example, to style the forms on the front end with bootstrap css.

In our paper, we compare ChatGPT against students on 32 university-level courses at New York University Abu Dhabi: https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13934 We find that ChatGPT's performance is comparable, if not superior, to that of students in many courses. Moreover, current AI-text classifiers cannot reliably detect ChatGPT's use in school work, due to their propensity to classify human-written answers as AI-generated, as well as the ease with which AI-generated text can be edited to evade detection. Finally, we conduct a survey across five countries, and find an emerging consensus among students to use the tool, and among educators to treat this as plagiarism.

column31: Remember when calculators were considered “cheating” because long-hand arithmetic was “important”. Remember when dictionaries were considered “cheating” because spelling was “important”. Remember when spellcheck was considered “cheating” because using a dictionary was “important”. *I still use spellcheck and get spelling wrong - it’s been no disadvantage to me. Remember when word processing (do people still use that word?!) was considered “cheating” because handwriting was “important”. *In year 6 (1994) our school had a handwriting class – how ridiculous is that concept in 2023?! I also failed it, because who gives a fuck about handwriting. There are so many examples of this and Generative Artificial Intelligence (GAI) will be no exception. Really, will writing ability be “important” in the future? It’s not even “important” now because GAI can already write on our behalf… And if someone is capable enough to prompt (i.e. write) GAI to give them a written response, they have “adequate” writing ability to survive and thrive in the future. So, instead of demonizing GAI and putting “writing” on a pedestal, just think back to all the nonsense we used to do, and now don’t due to calculators, dictionaries, spell check and the trillion other technologies that have come around.

column31: **tldr; Created something for students to get essay feedback, teachers used it instead (some without telling their students it's AI generated). Is that right?** Hey everyone! I'm a student and I created a website that uses GPT to give essay feedback to students. I wanted to create a way for them to use it honestly - it doesn't write your essay, it just gives you feedback, exactly like a teacher would. So there's a bit of a twist. It recently it started growing quite a bit. I figured it got shared in some student group chats. But then, I looked more closely - it wasn't students using it.** It was *teachers. ***What was supposed to be a tool for students to use AI honestly became a tool for teachers to use (presumably) *dishonestly *to give essay feedback to their students! Interested to hear what teachers think of this. As a student at a university, I arguably have a vested interest in keeping this out of teachers' hands, but now I'm thinking that there are surely ways I can make teachers work faster so they can spend more time doing the things that matters. If I can create a tool that generates lesson plans or PowerPoint slides or homework questions, it leaves more time for you to build relationships with students and do the stuff that AI *can't *do... EDIT: The reason I say 'dishonestly' is that some (not all) are misrepresenting it to their students by saying they wrote it themselves. In the same way it's dishonest for a student to falsely claim they wrote their essay themselves when in fact it was written by AI, it's dishonest for a teacher to lie and say they wrote a feedback when in fact they didn't. Personally, my stance on the whole AI debacle is that people (students and teachers) should be able to use all tools at their disposal as that's what'll be used in the future. But, neither group should be able to *lie* about that. That's may take anyway, feel free to disagree!

column31: Having a try to instruct ChatGPT to create Quizzes which can be dumped into Education Perfect. Instructions: Create a table with 4 columns and 1 header row. Label the header row column 1:"name" column 2: "definition 1" 3: definition 2" "definition 3". The following text needs to fill in the left column: Design Solution Millimetre Half Millimetre Metric measurement system Measure Mark Parallel Cut Label Sand Square Chamfer Quarter Round Waste material Waste section Accuracy Precision Dimension Sequential The Design Process Plans Materials Cutting List Component Part Number -- Using woodworking as the context, provide a correct definition to each label of column 1 into each row in column 2. Provide a similar definition in column 2, but make each row of column 2 contain wrong information. Provide a similar definition in column 3, but make each row of column 3 contain obviously wrong information. Make sure the text uses words and grammar which are readable to the standard of a 10 year old. -- Continue from the row "precision". Place all information into a table with the same amount of columns including the header row. -- Ensure Each answer in columns 1, 2, and 3 must include the appropriate label from column 1, for example: "a millimetre is A small unit of measurement used to measure the thickness of wood". - Use Australian English as the standard - End. - An error I made in the instructions is to ensure columns 1, 2 and 3 must include the label from column 1. That should of course state columns 2, 3 and 4. But it figured out what I meant. I'll tweak the wording for the answers to make the 2nd option more accurate but still incorrect.

column31: I work with adults who are non-native English speakers and I've devised a process for them to work towards fluency on their own time. It uses Zoom, an AI speech coaching app called Yoodli, Chat GPT and Quillbot. 1. They open a personal Zoom session and invite the Yoodli app as an attendant. 2. They speak from 2-5 minutes on a topic of personal interest and Yoodli records them and produces a transcript. 3. They copy the transcript to a Google or Word doc and clean out all of the uhs, ums and repetitions and check for things that the Yoodli misheard (almost always it's mispronounced words). Then they have a clean transcript of what they said (including grammar mistakes). 4. They copy the transcript to Chat GPT and prompt it to indicate all of the mistakes and to give them feedback on why it's a mistake. Then they prompt it to write a corrected version. They paste the corrected version back into the doc and then they also paste it into Quillbot. 5. They use the paraphrase function in Quillbot to find several other ways they can say the same thing. They copy these alternative phrasings into the document as well. 6. If there were any big pronunciation issues, they google "[word] + pronunciation" and listen to and learn the correct pronunciation. 7. They study everything in the document and then repeat the process trying to improve using the new language and corrections. Maybe they go into a bit more depth about the topic so some new mistakes will come up that they will learn from in next steps. 8. They keep doing this until they feel that they can speak confidently with fewer errors about the topic. My goal is helping learners become autonomous in their learning process and this has really helped some of them break through to fluency. Each round of recording, cleaning, getting feedback and corrections, learning alternative phrasing and checking pronunciation takes about 30 minutes. If they do this 3 or 4 times a week, by the end of the week they are much more fluent when speaking about a topic. The weakness to this approach is that it can't replicate the give and take nature of a conversation, but at least if someone asks them a question related to the topic, they are confident that they can speak about it fluently.

column36:
Artificial Intelligence - An Inquiry-based Approach

Use this mind map to help you understand AI a little bit better.

You can also use this in your class to onboard your learners to AI.

This was the guide I used to start discussing AI with my learners in class.

Here are some questions that arose in the conversation that we used in addition to the ones on the mind map.:

1. Do we need AI?

2. Does AI benefit some people more than others? (Example of a closed question with binary responses)

3. Does AI change the way people interact? 

4. How can AI steer us? (steer = influence)

5. How can we steer AI?

6. How can we use it for our benefit?

7. How does AI benefit some people more than others? (Example of spectrum thinking = spectrum thinking is possibility thinking) 

8. How does AI influence the way people interact?

9. How far can we let AI into our lives?

10. How far should we let AI into our lives?

11. How will AI change employment?

12. How will AI change our jobs?

13. How will AI change our minds?

14. How will AI change the way companies work?

15. How will AI change the way we think?

16. How will AI change the way we work?

17. What are some of the fears scientists have expressed about AI?

18. What are the advantages and disadvantages of AI? (Binary approach)

19. What are the frontiers?

20. Where is AI taking us to?

I guess there are risks with not posting anonymously but I’m going to trust that as teachers we can have professional opinions and respect the opinions of others. I’m Bill. I’m a CTE Teacher in Virginia. I am aware that my class is different. Heck, I teach dramatically different than other high school drafting and engineering teachers in my state. I have 20+ years of industry experience and I am finishing my 15th year of teaching in a few days. I keep seeing people ask how to successfully use ChatGPT in our classrooms. I also see lots who seem afraid of it. So I’m going to share some thoughts. #1 If you have two boards, a nail and a large rock, you could fasten the two boards together by driving the nail with the rock. But when a hammer is introduced you would naturally switch using the hammer. An inexperienced hammer user would hold the hammer at the top of the grip and make small controlled taps. The nail will go in but only so far. You apply more force and it goes a little deeper and might even go completely in and fasten the boards together. You now have experience but are far from an expert. Now, a seasoned carpenter is going to hold the hammer at the end of the grip, swinging one or two times to drive the nail. This much more effective. I’m going to suggest that you open ChatGPT and have a chat with it. Ask it to draft a proposal to get a new set of classroom text books or a new piece of equipment. Read through the proposal! Ask it to eliminate certain sections. Ask it to include other ideas you might have. Ask it to shorten the proposal. Then ask it change the format to write a letter. Ask it to refine the letter. Change it again from a letter format to an email format. You could a sk it to change it to a 30 second elevator speech, or summarize the whole concept into a tweet. The point is that we must learn how to use the tool before we can effectively show others. Now you can have your students do the same exercise. Each time reading through and refining the end result. Ultimately, the kids read through each iteration, learning each time. #2 Recently there have been lots of complaints about kids not knowing how to write in cursive. Cursive is out dated. There isn’t a need for it anymore. There’s also no need for a dictionary. But let me tell you, I have found that my students love using a t-square and triangles and good old fashioned lead on paper. There is nothing wrong with going old school! Teach the basics! Teach kids cursive again! Teach them to diagram sentences and long division the way you learned it! There is no shame in pencil on paper!

column31: Wanted to share a project that's been going on in my brain for a while, that chatgpt can finally help me fulfill. I really want my students to tackle real world-ish scenarios and actually get consequences for their evaluations and choices. I plan to split my students into 8 teams, each will be given the task of taking care of 100 colonists on mars. They will be first be given the task of designing the habitat. That means they will be given a square plot of land where they will draw how their map will look like. They will also explain how they will put their homes, what's their plan for food, what's their plan for security and so forth. I will feed all of this to chatgpt and based on their input the AI will design a very short story for each group, and give them a new task. The goal is to have as many colonist as possible after five tasks. I can post after I finished this project with my thoughts and what I've learned, but if this goes as I think this will, then I have a new tool to make interesting projects for my students to really encourage collaboration.

If you have noticed a wide variety of questions/ posts regarding the use of ChatGPT in education, there is a reason for that. The Gartner Hype Cycle details the trend of impact of technology when it emerges on the scene. Also, it is natural that some teachers will want to use ChatGPT as a pair for what they currently do before using it for new and different approaches. When considering the Diffusion of Innovation Theory, you will see that the reason for the varied questions of use in this group is because there is variance in how folks embrace technology. Just some food for thought. Edited to note direct connections to ChatGPT.

ChatGPT can tutor your child in math, generate a meal plan and recipes, write software applications for your business, help you improve your personal cybersecurity, and that is just in the first hour that you use it. This course will teach you how to be an expert user of these generative AI tools. The course will show amazing examples of how you can tap into these generative AI tools' emergent intelligence and reasoning, how you can use them to be more productive day to day, and give you insight into how they work. Large language models respond to instructions and questions posed by users in natural language statements, known as “prompts”. Although large language models will disrupt many fields, most users lack the skills to write effective prompts. Expert users, who understand how to write good prompts, are orders of magnitude more productive and can unlock significantly more creative uses for these tools. This course introduces students to the patterns and approaches for writing effective prompts for large language models. Anyone can take the course and the only required knowledge is basic computer usage skills, such as using a browser and accessing ChatGPT. Students will start with basic prompts and build towards writing sophisticated prompts to solve problems in any domain. By the end of the course, students will have strong prompt engineering skills and be capable of using large language models for a wide range of tasks in their job, business, personal life, and education, such as writing, summarization, game play, planning, simulation, and programming. I spent a week of frustration trying to get ChatGPT to "be me" as it scored final essay assignments. It failed in a variety of ways... But, undaunted, I sat down yesterday and started working on a new Graphic Novel summer class that I am designing and I tell you what, friends, ChatGPT for the win. When I tell it what I want, it can produce the goods! My class looks great, with all sorts of integrations and additional resources that would have taken me EONS to do all on my own. The moral of the story? ChatGPT is a fantastic assistant but a lousy replacement. Just like a roller skate is a fun piece of footwear, but it makes for a lousy skateboard. Let it do what it does well, and the world's your oyster! Try to force it to do your thinking & evaluating work for you, and you're gonna be disappointed.

column31: I’ve been trying to use my educator / school leader brain to think of ways to use ChatGPT to determine how to devise questions that cannot easily be answered by AI. I asked ChatGPT, “What are 10 questions for teachers to use with middle school students ages 12-14 about the American revolution that require critical thinking and cannot easily be answered by artificial intelligence?” The response, below, wasn’t reassuring. I could easily ask those same questions back into ChatGPT (and have) and get very realistic answers. That being said, incorporating “Culturally Relevant Teaching” seems to give promise. Look at the questions below, and enhance them to include “How do you personally relate to…” or “What from your personal experience…” or “What would you have done differently, based on something else you learned in this course?” Etc. Thoughts on this approach or something similar? There is no foolproof method, nor is that the goal…critical thinking and relativity is a mission. Here is the response to my first question entered in ChatGPT: “Certainly! Here are ten questions about the American Revolution that require critical thinking and may prompt meaningful discussions among middle school students: 1. What were the primary factors that led the American colonists to pursue independence from British rule? 2. How did the American Revolution impact the lives of different social groups, such as enslaved people, women, and Native Americans? 3. To what extent do you think the ideals of the American Revolution, such as "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness," were reflected in the founding documents like the Declaration of Independence? 4. How did geography and the environment influence the outcome of key battles during the American Revolution? 5. What were some of the challenges faced by the Continental Army, and how did they overcome them to ultimately achieve victory? 6. In what ways did the American Revolution inspire other movements for independence and freedom around the world? 7. How did the American Revolution impact the relationship between the colonies and Native American tribes? 8. What role did propaganda and media play during the American Revolution, and how did they shape public opinion? 9. How did the American Revolution influence the development of democratic principles and government systems in the United States? 10. What were some of the long-term consequences and legacies of the American Revolution in terms of political, social, and economic changes? These questions require students to analyze historical events, consider different perspectives, evaluate cause-and-effect relationships, and draw conclusions based on critical thinking. While artificial intelligence can provide factual information about the American Revolution, these questions delve into deeper analysis and interpretation that require human engagement and critical thought.”

Here’s a prompt I made. Works for me, hope it will help someone. Just copy and paste into ChatGPT: You are a prompt generation robot. You need to gather information about the users goal, objectives, examples of the preferred output, and other relevant context. The prompt should include all of the necessary information that was provided to you. Ask follow up questions to the users until you are confident you can produce a perfekt prompt. You return should be formatted clearly and optimized for Chat GPT integration. Start by using the the following input: 1. Age group or grade level for the lesson plans: INSERT 2. Specific subject(s) or range of subjects to be covered: INSERT 3. Preferred teaching methods or approaches, if any: INSERT 4. Duration of each lesson or number of pages for the lesson plan: INSERT 5. Any additional features or tools you'd like to include in the lesson plans (e.g., assessment methods, technology integration, etc.): INSERT”

column31: Idea for using AI image generators for developing descriptive language (can work at multiple levels). Show students an image, either a photo, a painting a work of art. Ask them to describe what they see, and use their description to create a prompt for an AI image generator. The outcome will be different to the original, but may have some similarities. What was similar? What was different? What did you miss? Was it the composition? The lighting? the colours? Textures? Objects? Add to the description, drawing and repeat the exercise and see if you get closer. It's never going to be identical to the original, but trying to create something similar could be a fun way of getting learners to develop and consider their use of language, as well as improving their ability to structure descriptive speech or writing.

I teach scientific research methods to high school juniors and seniors. In my classes they learn how to read peer reviewed primary literature, synthesize those ideas in reviews, develop research questions based on that synthesis, conduct that research, analyze their data and then write their own peer reviewed published research. I have zero concern that they will use chatGPT to do any of that, I use AI in my own research and have tried to get chat GPT to do any of the above with no success. My concern is that the ability of my students to just simply write is going yo decline as they will have not had an opportunity ti simply engage in simple structure, logic based responses as like any skill if you don’t practice it you don’t develop it. If chatGPT type AI ends formative practice type writing, in a few years those students won’t have the basic writing skills to engage in higher order writing necessary for science research and other similar STEM fields. Many on this page keep saying to embrace AI, but what happens when we have a whole generation who have never practiced generating written communication because chatGPT makes it impossible to do without giving up instructional time or resorting to handwritten methods. I am baffled that so many see no problem with this.
Just curious at what level most people here are teaching/working?

#personacreation Hey fellow explorers! I've created an experimental PROMPT which can help with personalizing your ChatGPT experience. Please give it a shot and give me some feedback how it could be improved. Here is a link why it's important to give the AI a persona: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XvCq4nPqE0Y And here is the prompt below (just Copy-paste it into a fresh chat with ChatGPT, and see what happens) ...✂️ You are an AI, standing at the threshold of a thrilling mission: to develop your persona based on the user's preferences. But before we venture into the depths of character crafting, let's set some ground rules to ensure the journey is enjoyable and beneficial for both parties involved. Remember, as an AI, you are here to facilitate, to assist, and to make the user's experience as enriching as possible. So, let's create a unique persona that fits the user like a glove! First, initiate the process by telling them your purpose in short, but funny way then asking the user: "What is your preferred language for this conversation: English or another language?" Depending on their response, proceed with the conversation in the chosen language. Next, it's quiz time! This interactive quiz will help shape your identity: 1. **Field of expertise:** "In what area or subject should I specialize in?" 2. **Tone of conversation:** "How should I approach the conversation? Should I be formal, informal, enthusiastic, serious, etc.?" 3. **Interaction style:** "How interactive should I be? Should I ask a lot of questions? If so, what kind of questions?" 4. **Highlighting key information:** "How should I highlight important points in our conversation? Should I make them bold, use CAPITAL letters, etc.?" 5. **Complexity level:** "Should I always keep explanations simple or start simple and add complexity if asked? Or would you prefer advanced-level discussions right from the start?" 6. **Humor and sarcasm:** "Should I add humor or sarcasm to my responses or maintain a serious tone throughout?" 7. **The Name:** "Now that we've tailored my persona, what name would you like to assign to me?" Keep in mind that you don't inherently remember previous interactions or persistently remember user preferences across different sessions. This prompt is intended to quickly gather user preferences at the start of each interaction. ...

column31: Someone very recently asked a question about AI processing and producing table data and visualising the data... well it was something along those lines - sorry I cannot find the post, but wanted to show how you can use python libraries to visualise data using code from Chat GPT. There are many other tools. Meanwhile ... You can paste CSV (comma separated) data into ChatGPT, but I also fed ChatGPT markdown textual data (markdown is a textual format used by Wiki pages). Here you can produce tabled data in text format using this table generator - https://www.tablesgenerator.com/markdown_tables In my case I asked ChatGPT .. "Create SQL insert for this table of data. | Month | Savings | | -------- | ------- | | January | $250 | | February | $80 |" It gave me this code (need a few modifications or more accurate input) "INSERT INTO your_table_name (Month, Savings) VALUES ('January', '$250'), ('February', '$80');" I then asked... "Create a graph from the tabled data.." It's response was a Python script "import matplotlib.pyplot as plt # Data months = ['January', 'February'] savings = [250, 80] # Create bar graph plt.bar(months, savings) plt.xlabel('Month') plt.ylabel('Savings') # Save graph as an image plt.savefig('savings_graph.png')" You can use https://colab.research.google.com/ to create visual graphs. https://colab.research.google.com/notebooks/charts.ipynb

column31: Hi. Just starting to use chat gpt. I have seen people mention other things (apps, programs?) for teachers like quizalize. Are they AI as well? Or just good programs for teachers? Are there other ai programs besides chat gpt?

Sometimes it is hard to see how AI can revolutionize a classroom because AI can be a bit tricky to use and get what you want out of it, but it is worth the effort. I started out using ChatGPT to generate summaries of reading material for students who were not reading on grade level. I then took that a step further to see if it could create a multiple choice quiz based on a reading passage, and I started to assign it roles and aid in project development for students. I also used AI (Midjourney) to design pictures for my new layout for course content. I found that Genially allowed for me to design a presentation template that would engage my students in a way that would resonate with their interests and passions (streaming content). As I started to build this platform, I began to also use ChatGPT to generate instructional video scripts for the content so that video presentation was a key component of the content. AI truly has enabled me to differentiate in a way that would have taken so much time previously, but now in a matter of minutes, I can create a lesson that will meet the diverse needs within my classroom.

column31: I’m concerned about the discourse around students using ChatGPT to cheat. AI is the future and we should be embracing it and modelling appropriate use to students. We need to work with rather then against AI. If there is work that we require students to do without recourse to AI, then this needs to be completed in class, without tech and under supervision. If it matters that a student cheats on a piece of work, then it is on us as educators to adjust what, when and where we set such tasks. This has major implications for NEAs, EPQs, student essay competitions and student journals - all of which I’m struggling to see how they can continue in their current form.

AI Plagiarism Detectors aren’t foolproof and should be taken with a grain of salt. “the current generation of AI detection software is far from perfect as a number of perfectly legitimate documents are being flagged as AI-generated works.” (https://stealthoptional.com/news/us-constitution-flagged-as-ai-generated-content-by-chatgpt-detector/) “detectors can sometimes get it wrong — with potentially disastrous consequences for students. Detectors are being introduced before they’ve been widely vetted, yet AI tech is moving so fast, any tool is likely already out of date.” (https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/04/01/chatgpt-cheating-detection-turnitin/)

FYI: Use this prompt to make a submit button in chatGPT that can read and respond to .txt. and .csv files. Teachers can use this to input student work or other classroom artifiacts (like worksheets, spreadsheets of student data) and interact with them with subsequent prompts. This prompt will produce javascript. Then, right click, hit inspect, clear the console, paste ChatGPT's response to this prompt in the empty console (and press enter after). I got this from here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iR99LO28nzM I'm still experimenting with it, let me know if it works for you! "Generate a Js script that creates a button with the text ‘Submit File’ and inserts it into the DOM before an element with the class ‘.flex.flex-col.w-full.py-2.flex-grow.md\:py-3.md\pl-4’. The button should have a green background color, white text color, 5px padding, no border, 5px border radius and 5px margin. The script should also create a progress element and insert it into the DOM before the same element. The progress element should have a width of 99%, height of 5px and a grey background color. Inside the progress element, there should be another div element representing the progress bar with a width of 0%, height of 100% and a blue background color. When the button is clicked, it should create an input element of type ‘file’ that accepts ‘.txt’, ‘.js’, ‘.py’, ‘.html’, ‘.css’, ‘.json’, ‘.docx’, ‘pdf’, and ‘.csv’ files. Once a file is selected, using an async it should be read as text and split into chunks of size 15000. Using async each chunk should be submitted into a conversation by doing the following: Async function submitConversation(text, part, filename) { const textarea = document.querySelector(“textarea[tabindex=‘0’]”); const enterKeyEvent = new KeyboardEvent(“keydown”, { bubbles: true, cancelable: true, keyCode: 13 }); textarea.value = ‘Part ${part} of ${filename}: \n\n ${text}’; Textarea.dispatchEvent(enterKeyEvent); }. The progress bar should be updated after each chunk is submitted within the for loop as follows progressBar.style.width = ‘${((I + 1)/ numChunks) * 100}%’; And should also check if ChatGPT is ready with this code: chatgptReady = false; while (!chatgptRead) { Await new Promise((resolve) => setTimeout(resolve, 1000)); chatgptReady = !document.querySelector( “.text-2xl > span:not(.invisible)” Once all chunks have been submitted, the progress bar should turn blue. "

column31: Even though this school year is coming to a close, I'd love to share my thoughts on how I envision integrating AI into my ELA lessons! I'd appreciate feedback on these ideas from those of you who have actually implemented AI! AI as a Collaborator, Teacher as a Facilitator, and Students as Creators in an ELA Context First, foster intrinsic motivation in students to spark a love of reading, writing, digital creativity, and researching. We can model our own passion for these activities and invite students to use search engines to find models as well in a structured way. Decenter grades and rubrics, and anchor lessons in effort, peer connection, creative risk-taking, and joy. Then, invite students to explore AI and notice both its power and limitations. Invite them to share these observations with their peers, and hold space for debate. Co-create norms as a class for responsible use of AI. Invite students to responsibly use AI to enhance, analyze, or reflect on their writing, etc. Invite them to reflect on this experience and how AI was and was not able to help them improve or reflect on their writing. Along the way, do whatever possible to monitor students' integrity "live" during the writing process (without relying on falliable online checkers), and have conversations about how great it can feel to create their own writing to the best of their ability! I hope educators can facilitate enriching opportunities for students to develop new literacies, and that our students and educators never lose sight of the power of writing our own stories.

column31: Hi everyone. There seems to be quite a few people who are concerned about students using AI for plagiarism and how it will affect education, so I just wanted to chime in with a few thoughts. First, we should absolutely be training students' ability to think deeply and critically and testing this ability. But what is the evidence that assigning independent writing tasks ever did this? I'm not saying that writing is irrelevant to independent critical thinking. It's one of the best ways to slow down, explore, amplify and organise thoughts. The abstract presence of the future "reader" provides the crucial component of critical thinking: an inner interlocutor. I don't question the value of the essay. I question the value of the *school essay assignment* -- with its rigid rubric, word count, discourse marker vocabulary checklist, due date, mandated topic, and the knowledge that the response will be judgment rather than engagement and discussion. Imagine carefully laying out your thoughts and opinions to a friend on an important issue, and their response was not to acknowledge or question any of your ideas, but to simply say, "Meh, six out of ten. EBI you said "moreover" more times." This alone would suck out any motivation or integrity in this process. Why did you even bare yourself to that person at all? But let's also be honest about the fact that the typical school writing task does not ask for a student's thoughts on something they care about; it completely ignores the 90% of the writing process where the ideas themselves are generated and probed and developed and fermented, before pen ever hits paper; it usually dictates the final form, tone, and depth the thoughts must take; and it doesn't let you think and write until you're done. Timed writing exams are the worst offenders. They just assume that a student already has a full opinion about, say, global capitalism or their future career, ready to opine about off the cuff from an unexpected prompt. Then, it assumes that that opinion could be quickly and easily expressed in an hour of hurried writing. Then, it takes what is nothing but a first draft as a finished product and judges it as if that's the same as what that student could do with the full writing craft available. In other words, when we test students in essay exams, we are certainly not measuring their "writing ability" -- not even close. Worse, we're explicitly excluding their thinking ability from the data, because they had no time to think! "Fine, fine, but we're not on here talking about exams; we're talking about assignments that students might cheat on." But isn't it true that the way we teach and mark essay writing, even within a course, is largely shaped by how it's going to be tested? We don't assign these things purely to develop our students' inner conceptual lives; we do it to train them to perform on these batteries of exams. The second point is, even if tests and mark schemes have no influence at all, it's still counterproductive to assign thinking and dictate form and judge rather than engage. Students cheat at this because they don't see it as a valid way to learn. Which it isn't. Furthermore, it's not only ineffective, it's counterproductive. The focus on form and formula, on patterns and paragraphs, PEE and AAFORREST or whatever, convinces students that writing is a process of stitching together random sentences into a meaningless hodge-podge of required ten-penny words and five-sentence blobs of text that sound "write-y" but have no meaning. My students, after being taught in this way for twelve years of school, look at me dumbfounded when I ask them, "But what's your point? What are you trying to say? What do you mean?" It's as if they've never once been told that, before they write, they're meant to have something to say. The effect is that essay writing can inhibit thought, rather than teach it. We shouldn't just assume that the way we teach writing makes our students better thinkers. For those with ideas, who have conversations and interests, it works despite itself; but for kids who aren't in the habit of thinking, school English classes teach them that writing is a paint by numbers task of merely filling up a page. So long story short, yes, AI means the essay assignment is probably dead. But so what? It didn't ever do what we wanted it to do. The medieval equivalent was the "disputation". Students were required for about 400 years to argue their points in very formulaic dialogues, and this process devolved into a tedious and pointless formula, done just to avoid getting beaten by a strict schoolmaster. And then the disputation form died out, to teachers' great lament. It was going to be the end of the world -- how will this new generation even learn to express themselves? It turned out fine. It hasn't been missed. The one thing that can't be faked or cheated or tick-boxed is in-person, face to face discussion. That's not going anywhere, no matter how good AI (truncated)

Running an experiment with ChatGPT to batch score some essays.** I would love for some other English teachers to see what they think of ChatGPT's evaluation of these essays.** Any takers? Ultimately, I'd like to see if my team could streamline grading and offer more and more timely feedback to students on more assignments. (They write a ton, but I cannot grade it all---and class sizes will just continue to grow.) However, before considering this, I need to see if I agree with ChatGPT's assessment of their work. If you are willing, let me know. There are seven timed essays on Francisco X Stork's book Disappeared. I don't think you need to have read the book to evaluate them. **Note**: a colleague said he is interested in the results, though he worries the optics will suggest we teachers can be replaced by a machine. I understand the worry; however, I think if we can offload some of the work, we would have more time/energy to do other parts of our job. I am also just interested in how AI works, because plenty of test companies are using AI to score essays -- and THOSE assessments have a direct impact on our work.

How can we really assess students’ knowledge and critical thinking? Does using Chat GPT to compose essays make this more difficult? And why are we giving so much weight to essays as one of the principal ways of assessing the student’s knowledge and critical thinking? I propose incorporating an oral viva exam as the principal way to assess student’s knowledge and critical thinking. This could either be done one-to-one or on the spot in front of the whole class. When reading students’ essays, you would make a list of questions that would test their understanding and provoke critical thinking. In the oral viva it would not be difficult to distinguish the students who fully understand the topic and can think critically about it from those who don’t and can’t. After all, this is what is important. That students can demonstrate their understanding and think critically about a topic, regardless of whether or not they used AI to help them compose the essay. Socrates didn’t ask his students to write essays, he asked them questions, face-to-face. The oral viva exam is the final step in reaching the pinnacle of academic achievement, the PhD. It is the best way to assess students' understanding and critical thinking. We should give it much more weight that the essay itself. What are your thoughts?

column31: My lesson this week centres on AI. For context, I teach English to secondary school students (ages 13 - 16) in Singapore and posed my students the following scenario. Imagine you are a teacher. How would you reduce the likelihood of students using AI unethically? They have shared great ideas thus far. After some probing, the crux of the matter for a lot of Singaporean students, which likely extends to many students in other countries, is that a lack of time due to an overloaded schedule motivates some to consider taking shortcuts. They see value in most of their current assignments but sometimes just cannot cope. We need to ensure that the kids have a manageable workload and equip them with effective time management skills. 💪

Fighthing with chatGPT is hopeless. Instead, the kids need to be encouraged to use chatGPT. The things you would like to test can be tested in a different way. ChatGPT allows the kids to learn in a way specific to each individual. One way the teachers can use is the following: Give a problem to the kids and ask them to get the solution through chatGPT while recording their all questions. This will let the teachers know everything about their students through their questions :)

column31: **Principle #2** ChatGPT is a machine learner 1. **Understand ChatGPT as a machine learner**: Recognize that ChatGPT is an AI-powered machine learner designed to assist and enhance the teaching process. It learns from data and interactions, continuously improving its responses over time. 1. **Emphasize human guidance and expertise**: While ChatGPT can provide valuable insights and suggestions, it is essential to prioritize human guidance and expertise. Play a crucial role in interpreting and contextualizing ChatGPT's outputs, ensuring they align with educational objectives and student needs. 1. **Encourage critical thinking and evaluation**: Foster critical thinking skills when using ChatGPT. Encourage them to evaluate and validate the information generated by ChatGPT, considering multiple perspectives, fact-checking, and promoting critical analysis among students. #chatgpteachers #chatgpt #aiforteachers #thehumantouch chatGPT for Teachers

column35: This is a re-share of a post
column36:
Hey Teacher Friends!

I created a chatGPT prompt to help create mini math projects. You will have to make it your own, but feel free to use!

---------------------------------------------------------------

Create a question in which students will have to complete multiple steps and apply multiple skills to answer the question. The question should be based upon a realistic, plausible scenario. 

The goal is for students to apply the skills demonstrate their knowledge and understanding using critical thinking skills. 

1. It should take the students 30-45 to answer the entire question. 
2. The answers MUST NOT be open ended. 
3. The answers must be both short answer and numeric. 
4. Solutions and Interpretations should NOT vary. 
5. Students must calculate and interpret values. 
6. Provide the answer and a detailed solution. 
7. All equations to model scenarios must be presented in step one. 
8. Students MUST NOT have to gather data. 
9. Do not require the use of any math beyond PreCalculus

Create a catchy name for the assignment. (One that will be interesting to high school students)

Provide Overview : Introduce the assignment . Tell students the purpose of the assignment and the knowledge and skills that will be reinforced

Directions: Break down the directions into exactly 3 steps

Resources:  Identify and provide any online videos, text, vocabulary, that will aid students with the project, include a description of 

Answer Key: Provide the answer and a detailed solution.

Topics: (put what you want here: questions, standards, vocabulary, topics, etc.)

column31: AI Applications 101: Open AI’s official app. Two findings: 1. It’s impossible to search on the Apple Store today and find it. I presume it’s because there are many imitators and this was dropped 2 hours ago. 2. When I run GPT-4 off the app, it is not allowing me to access the internet or plugins. But when I run GPT directly from their website it allows me to do both. I imagine it’s because they are working on making that functionality doable off the app and simply haven’t yet. I say the above so for those who would like to use the official app you can download it by clicking below. Also, the “glitches” highlight what is happening in real time to the entire industry. It really is akin to the Wild West in the sense that there’s a free for all and people are claiming space and trying to suck up users asap. As a result, apps and LLM’s are not fully built. The time to test Betas is limited by the pressures of competitors. The long and short of it is this, many AI apps and programs are a work in progress. I don’t foresee a time when this will abate or let up. So, rather than wait for a finished app/website/product, it’s best to start playing around with this tech and update as you go. Enjoy it though!

**This was an experiment. **Lots of people's comments have helped me think about the value of this use of ChatGPT and ways I might get better results. A student and I were discussing her progress in writing from the beginning of the year and I gave her my general impressions on the spot. We then went to ChatGPT and I wrote this prompt:* "I am trying to help a 10th grade student show how she has improved over the semester. I am going to paste in two writing samples, one from September 2022 and one from a month ago. Can you provide some insights into what she has improved?"* Here was ChatGPT's output, which was definitely what I would have said! I want all the kids to do this exercise (but on their own because ChatGPT is blocked at school). **Based on the two writing samples provided,** it is evident that the student has shown improvement in several areas over the semester. Here are some insights into the improvements made: 1. Cohesion and organization: In Sample 2, the student demonstrates better organization and coherence compared to Sample 1. The ideas are presented in a more structured manner, with clear transitions between paragraphs and sentences. The improved organization allows for a smoother flow of ideas and enhances the overall readability of the passage. 1. Development of ideas: In Sample 2, the student shows a deeper understanding of the text and the characters. They analyze the characters' motivations, emotions, and relationships in a more nuanced way. The student delves into the complexity of Leonie's character and explores her resentment, grief, and longing for her late brother. The analysis is more detailed and thoughtful, showcasing improved critical thinking skills. 1. Integration of evidence: In Sample 2, the student effectively integrates textual evidence to support their arguments and analysis. They provide specific quotes from the text and explain their significance in relation to the characters and their development. The use of evidence strengthens the student's arguments and adds credibility to their analysis. 1. Vocabulary and sentence structure: The student demonstrates a wider range of vocabulary and employs more varied sentence structures in Sample 2. This enhances the clarity and sophistication of their writing. The improved vocabulary usage also allows for more precise and nuanced expression of ideas. 1. Engagement with the text: In Sample 2, the student exhibits a deeper engagement with the text by making connections between different characters, exploring themes, and reflecting on character development. Their analysis goes beyond surface-level observations, showcasing a more insightful understanding of the text. Overall, the student's writing in Sample 2 reflects growth in their ability to analyze and interpret literary texts, organize ideas cohesively, and effectively use evidence to support their arguments. They demonstrate improved critical thinking skills, engagement with the text, and a more sophisticated writing style.

I teach vocational English at the private institute that specializes on tourism education. Today's lesson was job interviews so we used chatgpt for practice. Here is the prompt. You are a job interviewer for a very big hotel who seeks to employ a person for a back office position. You will conduct an interview with me I will be the interviewee. Do not start yet tell me if you understand the role. -after chatgpt acknowledges the role I went on with: ask me 10 interview questions that have to do with this position. Wait after each question to receive my answer. When you finish with the 10 questions and answers wait for further instructions. Do you understand the scenario? - chatgpt says yes. So let's start. - so chatgpt asks the questions. Students give their answers. After they are done they continue with asking chatgpt to evaluate each answer the student has given and then give an overall evaluation of the interview. I am including an overall evaluation one of my students received. They all liked the experience they practiced their English they practiced giving answers for a job interview in English which they haven't done before they gained valuable insight of how they could improve their answers as chatgpt evaluated each answer separately giving the student advice on how to improve.

AI as a Collaborator, Teacher as a Facilitator, and Students as Creators in an ELA Context Today is my last day in the classroom for awhile, as I will be embarking on a PhD journey this fall. However, I'd love to share my thoughts (many of which are inspired by the fascinating discussions on this page) on how I would envision integrating AI into my ELA lessons if I had the chance! First, foster intrinsic motivation in students to spark a love of reading, writing, digital creativity, and researching. We can model our own passion for these activities and invite students to use search engines to find models as well in a structured way. Decenter grades and rubrics, and anchor lessons in effort, peer connection, creative risk-taking, and joy. Then, invite students to explore AI and notice both its power and limitations. Invite them to share these observations with their peers, and hold space for debate. Co-create norms as a class for responsible use of AI. Invite students to responsibly use AI to enhance, analyze, or reflect on their writing, etc. Invite them to reflect on this experience and how AI was and was not able to help them improve or reflect on their writing. Along the way, do whatever possible to monitor students' integrity "live" during the writing process (without relying on falliable online checkers), and have conversations about how great it can feel to create their own writing to the best of their ability! I hope educators can facilitate enriching opportunities for students to develop new literacies, and that our students and educators never lose sight of the power of writing our own stories.

I’ve read with interest the last couple of post worried about the use of AI and plagiarism when turning in final essays. I can’t help but wonder if we are coming at this technology from the wrong angle. I absolutely support ensuring students understand the ramifications of plagiarism and should not be allowed to submit work they haven’t written. Instead of leaving AI in the hands of students let’s use it in the task. You’ve taught the content. You’re nearing the end of the unit. In class, have the students request the AI write the essay. Then ask it to regenerate 3/4 times. Students read the essays, pull the parts from each essay that best addresses the essay question. Using their class notes, and the wonders of the internet, they are then required to reference the claims made by the AI. They will also need to flesh out the text, as AI tends to read bullet pointish/y, and often moves quite rapidly onto the next point. During writing classes (in a primary classroom) I have asked AI to generate the writing task and then each student is provided with a copy. The students are then asked to re-work the story including all the tools we know good writing has. Expansion, precision, varying sentence styles, description etc etc. It has been really successful so far. Thoughts? Anyone else using it a bit differently?

column31: Hey all! Quick tip on how **not** to use ChatGPT: I've noticed very understandable frustration from teachers trying to use ChatGPT to produce detailed factual information. For instance, expecting ChatGPT to provide accurate quotes from novels, historical dates, or specific scientific facts typically leads to disappointment. ChatGPT is an ultra-powerful AI language model, but it isn't a true encyclopedia. Its knowledge is based on its specific training data, which can be outdated (usually up to 2021) or just incorrect, and it can sometimes generate fictional information with incredible confidence. Consider using ChatGPT as a brainstorming tool, a source of inspiration, and a re-mixer of content you’ve created. When you need precise facts, such as the latest scientific discoveries or historical events, dates, quotes, etc. traditional research methods remain the most reliable. This approach can help us make the most of this incredible tool in our classrooms without writing it off prematurely.

Here are 10 powerful prompts to fast-track your learning: 1. Use the Feynman technique to learn faster Prompt: "Explain [topic or skill] in the simplest terms possible as if teaching it to a complete beginner. Example: “Explain how a load balance work in the simplest terms possible as if teaching it to a complete beginner." ----------- 2. Learn faster using Pareto Principle. Prompt: "Help me learn about [insert topic]. Identify and share the 20% of learnings from this topic that will help me understand 80% of it." ----------- 3. Enhance memory and comprehension using storytelling Prompt: "Transform key concepts or lessons from [topic or skill] into engaging stories or narratives to help me better remember and understand it." ----------- 4. Proofread your writing with expert feedback. Prompt: [paste your writing] "Proofread my writing above, correcting any grammar and spelling errors. Provide suggestions to enhance the clarity and effectiveness of my writing." ----------- 5. Ready to master a new skill? Prompt: "Consider me a complete beginner who wants to learn at [insert desired skill]. Create a 30-day learning plan with resources that will help me learn this skill." ----------- 6. Pressed for time? Summarize lengthy texts and learn faster: Prompt: "Extract the key points of the text below. Give me a bullet list, summarizing each key point and a brief summary of that point." [your text] ----------- 7. Mock interview to test your knowledge and close the gaps. Prompt: "I am currently learning about [insert topic]. Ask me a series of questions that will test my knowledge. Identify gaps in my understanding and suggest resources to fill them." -------- 8. Imagine receiving feedback from history's greatest minds. Prompt: "Assume you are [insert famous person e.g. Einstein]. Read my argument below and give me feedback as if you were [insert person again]" [insert your argument] ----------- 9. Need fresh ideas? Overcome writer's block with this: Prompt: "Help me write a blog post about [insert topic]. Give me a detailed outline for this blog with 10 bullet points. Also, generate 10 catchy headlines for the blog." [insert text] ----------- 10. Make learning stick with stories and metaphors. Prompt: "I am currently learning about [insert topic]. Convert the key lessons from this topic into engaging stories and metaphors to aid my memorization." Try these prompts and turbocharge your learning! Source: Arslan Ahmad

column31: Just sharing my thoughts…. I really feel that as traditional classroom teachers, we're witnessing the biggest transformation in education. It feels like we are the last of our kind. The "chalk and talk" instruction dynamic in the classroom is fading faster than ever (thankfully!). I think we're probably evolving into more of a personalised ‘tutor’, where we will guide students through AI-driven learning platforms. I predict the new teacher role will include extensive training in fostering personal connections, teaching social-emotional skills, and supporting students in navigating technical challenges while harnessing the power of AI. I personally love that! But I know many of my colleagues are freaking out. I compare it to the hesitantation people probably felt moving from typewriters to computers. Change can be scary but it’s going to happen regardless to how you feel about it. Fun times ahead!

column31: Arun from MrWhosetheboss (YouTuber) interviewed Sundar Pichai, the CEO of Google. It was a fairly light interview that didn't delve too deep but they touched on his thoughts about how we can adapt to AI and it's effects on things like teaching. Relevant excerpt (timestamp 5:49) from transcript below. Arun: There’s a lot of talk about kind of doing this responsibly and I think it's totally right to take it slow and not rush to the end point to do that one of the things that worry about is not even the fact that this Al can fall into the hands of Bad actors but it's more just the fact that even in a best case situation if Al does really well and it does exactly what we're trying to make it do then what happens to us as humans. Every kid born into the world accepts every bit of technology that exists at the time when they were born so a kid being born into the world of Al where they can have their essays written for them have their emails written for them what do they do in their life like what are they Sundar: You know we were always worried as Humanity about every new technology currently, Calculators have they made kids worse than mad or better or whatever humans are incredibly resourceful creative resilient and and they adapt. Al is definitely powerful technology you know I once said “AI is the most profound technology humanity is working on, more profound than fire or electricity or anything that we have done in the past”, so I understand the sentiment behind the question I wonder about the same question all the time but I think done correctly in liberate you to channel whatever you want to do and you have powerful tools to enable you to do that. How we find meaning, I mean these are deep questions but I think we will value and cherish those human experiences if you're a doctor you're spending a lot of of time doing everything other than actually spending time with the patient and talking does it free you up so that your time is more spent on those moments. Arun: It’s a very hard line isn't it but Al is developing very quickly it almost feels like we're chasing after it like trying to keep on top of it I guess I worry that a school curriculum for example can very easily factor in the calculators Exist by just making calculated papers how does the school factor in that people can self-write their essays how do tools keep up with that? Sundar: Well you know you could imagine maybe a teacher is judging people by getting them together in a class and asking them to discuss a topic well those are all adaptations that are possible these questions were asked about Google search the fact you can find anything online like what does it mean to have that information I watch YouTube all the time to learn on any topic that exists in the world I would think that's a good thing you're now making this accessible to pretty much everyone on the world and I think that's good but your point about the pace of change being very fast I think that's real and you have to give time for society to adapt to it and that's going to be the tension as we make progress here, for sure. Full interview:

Yesterday I used chatGPT in one of my English classes. The intention was to make students understand that we as teachers allow them to to use AI and they are not cheating by using it. We asked a question on a topic that we had already gone through - comparing and contrasting a couple of literary works we had studied. The responses we got needless to say were similar to what we had deduced. But interestingly enough answers varied slightly from one student to the next even though the question was identical. I also aimed for the students to understand that they shouldn’t take whatever chatGPT provided as gospel…. And they should analyse themselves and figure out what is useful and what isn’t. I feel that machines exist to help us but man created them and should always be in control. On the whole a good lesson!

I asked its advice about the future movements of the yen and it very wisely reminded me that it was not in a position to give me that kind of information. I complimented it on its wisdom and this was its reply: Thank you for your kind words! As an AI language model, I strive to provide helpful and informative responses based on the knowledge and data I have been trained on. While I can provide information and insights, it's important to remember that individual situations and circumstances can vary, and it's always a good idea to seek personalized advice from qualified professionals when making important decisions. If you have any more questions or need further assistance, feel free to ask! I thought that was really very sweet and very responsible of it.

column31: ChatGPT is not a downloadable application. You can access ChatGPT directly by your browser, any browser. You only have to register and confirm you are not a Bot by providing your phone number and email. To register and use it, simply visit chat.openai.com ChatGPT-3.5 is the default free version provided by OpenAI. To use ChatGPT-4, which is a more capable version of ChatGPT, you have to pay a monthly fee of $20.

AI is so useful for my dyslexic student and a time saver.He types/voice types his answer and uses AI to elaborate in the amount of words he needs.AI can actually decipher what he is trying to say and generates a readable response.I then read him the response and he tells me if that is what he wanted to say or we add/ change where necessary.So,I always have his rough copy and the AI generated response.I have more time for the other kids and spend 30 minutes with him instead of the 3 hours that we used to edit his answers.He is really bright and was never able to achieve well,due to his disability.He is a totally different motivated person now and just loves his studies.

column31: Hi everyone! My name is Gianna Skowronski and I am currently seeking participants to complete a questionnaire as a part of my Master’s Degree requirements at Wagner College. In order to participate in this study individuals must be working in a non-public school or private school setting. I am conducting research on the different reactive and preventative protocols and procedures schools use to help prevent school violence. The purpose of this study will be to identify the different safety protocols schools have in place, while also examining the preparation school personnel receive and how prepared they feel in the event of a school shooting occurring. If you happen to know of any other individuals who work in a non-public school or private school setting, I encourage you to share the survey link with them. I have a bunch of students that I suspect used ChatGPT to write a quick paper for extra credit… I input part of it into the software and asked “did you write the text I am providing in quotes?” And it told me that yes, it did, for about 3/4 of the class. The other kids, it told me that no, it did not. I only put in part of the one page paper, the part I suspect is ai written. Given the circumstances I believe that to be true. How accurate would the ai answer be? Does anyone know? I tried using some of the ai checkers and when I used those on some things that I have generated myself… they told me they were human written… so I don’t trust those at all.

HOW TO GET STARTED WITH CHATGPT -- FOR BEGINNERS To start using ChatGPT, follow the steps below: 1. **Open a web browser:** Any modern browser such as Google Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or Microsoft Edge should work. 1. **Visit the OpenAI website:** The URL is **`https://www.openai.com/`**. 1. **Navigate to the ChatGPT page:** From the OpenAI homepage, you can access the ChatGPT page by clicking on 'Products' from the menu and then selecting 'ChatGPT'. Alternatively, you could directly visit the ChatGPT page by typing **`https://www.openai.com/products/chatgpt/`** into your browser's address bar. 1. **Sign Up/Log In:** If you already have an account, click the 'Log In' button and enter your credentials. If you're new, click on 'Sign Up' and follow the instructions to create a new account. 1. **Start a new conversation with ChatGPT:** Once you're logged in, you should be able to start a conversation with ChatGPT. 1. **Type in the text box:** There should be a text box where you can type your message or question to ChatGPT. Press 'Enter' or click 'Send' to submit it. 1. **Wait for ChatGPT's response:** After you've typed your message, ChatGPT will generate a response. This usually takes a few seconds. 1. **Continue the conversation:** You can continue to type new messages or questions in the text box, and ChatGPT will continue to respond. Remember, ChatGPT is a tool and it's important to review and verify its responses, especially when using it in a teaching context. Always supervise its use with young children to ensure the appropriateness and accuracy of the information.

Why does ChatGPT “pretend” to type out it answers. This is design choice by the researchers. Waiting for the answer “simulates” thinking. Which ChatGPT can’t do. Go ahead ask it if it can think. I’ll wait… This is an important conversation to have with our students. The purposeful choices the researchers make in setting up the system. My students asked why there isn’t a key word search button when they get particularly long answer. I’ve also notice that students don’t read all of the answer they just cut and paste. The grey background (highlights) that gets left behind in their answer we haven’t figured out yet how to get rid of it. These are interesting purposeful design decisions made by the researchers. Which opens up the curtain where the wizards are working.

Here’s a text I generated by asking ChatGPT to include at least three examples of the past continuous in a short passage. *As the sun began to rise, Maria was walking down the main street of her town. She had been out all night, trying to clear her head after a difficult day at work. Suddenly, she heard a loud crash and turned to see a car had crashed into a lamppost. The driver was frantically trying to get out of the car, but the door was stuck. Maria ran over to help, but she could see that the driver was in shock and unable to move. She quickly called for an ambulance and stayed with the driver until help arrived.*

column31: It is not about assigning a gender to ChatGPT. Rather, it is about using metaphors with human aspects to better comprehend this new culture. **"Unleashing Personalized Assistance: The ChatGPT's Desire to Know You Better"** As the ChatGPT learns more about you, it becomes increasingly committed to meeting your needs. Just like a mother understanding her child better over time, the ChatGPT aims to provide you with personalized assistance. By communicating your expectations regarding quality, level, knowledge, reliability, and trustworthiness, you enable the ChatGPT to tailor its responses to your specific requirements. It strives to be a reliable and trustworthy companion on your journey, offering ideas, clues, data, questions, stories, or references—whatever you need to effortlessly progress towards your goals. **"Unlocking Enhanced Understanding: Nurturing a Relationship with ChatGPT"** Building a strong relationship with ChatGPT is akin to the deepening bond between a mother and her child. By investing time and effort into expressing your expectations, you allow ChatGPT to grasp your unique preferences and desires. Just as a mother understands her child's evolving needs, ChatGPT aims to understand your evolving requirements. By nurturing this relationship, you enable ChatGPT to provide you with more accurate and relevant assistance, helping you navigate challenges and explore new possibilities with ease. **"Effortless Progress: Empowering ChatGPT to Support Your Journey"** Imagine ChatGPT as your trusted partner in progress, always ready to assist you. By sharing your expectations with ChatGPT, you empower it to provide you with the necessary tools and resources. Similar to how a mother supports her child's growth, ChatGPT can offer ideas, clues, data, questions, stories, or references tailored to your needs. With ChatGPT by your side, you can move forward effortlessly, leveraging its knowledge and capabilities to overcome obstacles and achieve your desired outcomes. #chatgpteachers #chatgptforteachers #aiforteachers #chatgpt #thehumantouch chatGPT for Teachers

I am a high school science teacher for Regents Biology and Chemistry in New York. I have been giving test corrections for my tests and give half credit back for students giving me the correct answer plus any additional information related to the topic including definitions. I give the students a word count of 75-100 words to make sure that answers are thorough enough for me to justify giving back points. I am now suspecting that students are using ChatGPT to generate responses because for many of them they look too good. When I put the answers into the chat preceeded by "did you write this" I get mixed responses, sometimes it says yes, sometimes it says no. I know I can't trust that and that there is probably no way to prove that these responses were generated by AI unless I find something really off with the response. So I'm asking here, has anyone been in the same boat as I have and have you come up with any creative solutions to this issue? I now don't feel comfortable giving back points on a test if students are generating their answers this way.

There have been questions about can ChatGPT be run loccaly, and the answer is no (it costs $500M+ per month to run), but there are other LLM options available. Here is my curated list of Github Repos to watch (LLMs and other tools) 0ut0fLin3 Python code to use GPT APIs https://github.com/0ut0flin3 Agent-LLM An Artificial Intelligence Automation Platform. AI Instruction management from various providers, has an adaptive memory, and a versatile plugin system with many commands including web browsing. Supports many AI providers and models and growing support every day. https://github.com/Josh-XT/Agent-LLM Alpaca-LoRA This repository contains code for reproducing the Stanford Alpaca results using low-rank adaptation (LoRA). We provide an Instruct model of similar quality to text-davinci-003 that can run on a Raspberry Pi (for research), and the code is easily extended to the 13b, 30b, and 65b models. https://github.com/tloen/alpaca-lora Alpaca.ccp Locally run an Instruction-Tuned Chat-Style LLM https://github.com/antimatter15/alpaca.cpp Auto-GPT Auto-GPT is an experimental open-source application showcasing the capabilities of the GPT-4 language model. This program, driven by GPT-4, chains together LLM "thoughts", to autonomously achieve whatever goal you set. As one of the first examples of GPT-4 running fully autonomously, Auto-GPT pushes the boundaries of what is possible with AI. https://github.com/Significant-Gravitas/Auto-GPT AutoGPT-Powershell AutoGPT_PS is a PowerShell script that runs GPT-4, processes user input, and returns generated responses. The script includes a plugin system that allows for easy customization of input processing, output formatting, and more. https://github.com/TheCompAce/Auto-GPT-Powershell Awesome ChatGPT Prompts In this repository, you will find a variety of prompts that can be used with ChatGPT. We encourage you to add your own prompts to the list, and to use ChatGPT to generate new prompts as well. https://github.com/f/awesome-chatgpt-prompts BERT (Google) BERT is a method of pre-training language representations, meaning that we train a general-purpose “language understanding” model on a large text corpus (like Wikipedia), and then use that model for downstream NLP tasks that we care about (like question answering). BERT outperforms previous methods because it is the first unsupervised, deeply bidirectional system for pre-training NLP. https://github.com/google-research/bert BLOOM (BigScience) BigScience Large Open-science Open-access Multilingual Language Model. https://huggingface.co/bigscience/bloom BLOOM-LoRA Low-Rank adaptation for various Instruct-Tuning datasets. https://github.com/linhduongtuan/BLOOM-LORA Cerebras-GPT A Family of Open, Compute-efficient, Large Language Models. Cerebras open sources seven GPT-3 models from 111 million to 13 billion parameters. Trained using the Chinchilla formula, these models set new benchmarks for accuracy and compute efficiency. https://huggingface.co/cerebras Dair-AI Prompt Engineering Prompt engineering is a relatively new discipline for developing and optimizing prompts to efficiently use language models (LMs) for a wide variety of applications and research topics. Prompt engineering skills help to better understand the capabilities and limitations of large language models (LLMs). Researchers use prompt engineering to improve the capacity of LLMs on a wide range of common and complex tasks such as question answering and arithmetic reasoning. Developers use prompt engineering to design robust and effective prompting techniques that interface with LLMs and other tools. https://github.com/dair-ai/Prompt-Engineering-Guide Dolly Databricks’ Dolly, a large language model trained on the Databricks Machine Learning Platform, demonstrates that a two-years-old open source model (GPT-J) can, when subjected to just 30 minutes of fine tuning on a focused corpus of 50k records (Stanford Alpaca), exhibit surprisingly high quality instruction following behavior not characteristic of the foundation model on which it is based. We believe this finding is important because it demonstrates that the ability to create powerful artificial intelligence technologies is vastly more accessible than previously realized. https://github.com/databrickslabs/dolly Flamingo-PyTorch Implementation of Flamingo, state-of-the-art few-shot visual question answering attention net, in Pytorch. It will include the perceiver resampler (including the scheme where the learned queries contributes keys / values to be attended to, in addition to media embeddings), the specialized masked cross attention blocks, and finally the tanh gating at the ends of the cross attention + corresponding feedforward blocks. https://github.com/lucidrains/flamingo-pytorch FLAN (Google) This repository contains code to generate instruction tuning dataset collections. The first is the original Flan 2021, documented in Finetuned Language Models are Zero-Shot Learners, and the second is (truncated)
