Bard grades an essay done by ChatGPT 19/20. He says the introduction is too long: Title: The Importance of Being Healthy: A Path to a Happy Life Introduction: Being healthy is a vital aspect of our lives. It ensures that we can enjoy life to the fullest and accomplish our goals. In this essay, we will explore the significance of leading a healthy lifestyle and discover different ways to achieve it. Body: 1. Physical Health: Maintaining good physical health is crucial for our overall well-being. Here are some key ways to stay physically healthy: a) Balanced Diet: Eating a variety of nutritious foods, including fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins, provides our bodies with the necessary nutrients to function properly. b) Regular Exercise: Engaging in physical activities, such as playing sports, cycling, or dancing, helps strengthen our muscles, maintain a healthy weight, and improve our cardiovascular health. c) Adequate Sleep: Getting enough sleep is essential for our bodies to rest and recharge. It allows us to stay focused, be more productive, and have enough energy throughout the day. 2. Mental and Emotional Health: Taking care of our mental and emotional well-being is equally important. Here are some ways to promote good mental and emotional health: a) Positive Relationships: Surrounding ourselves with supportive family and friends creates a strong network of emotional support. Spending quality time with loved ones and sharing our thoughts and feelings helps reduce stress and boosts happiness. b) Managing Stress: Stress is a normal part of life, but learning healthy ways to manage it is essential. Engaging in activities such as reading, listening to music, practicing deep breathing, or pursuing hobbies can help reduce stress levels. c) Expressing Emotions: It is crucial to express our emotions in a healthy way. Talking to someone we trust, such as a parent, teacher, or counselor, can provide us with guidance and support during challenging times. 3. Hygiene and Safety: Maintaining proper hygiene and safety habits is necessary for our well-being. Here are some important practices to remember: a) Handwashing: Regular handwashing helps prevent the spread of germs and keeps us healthy. We should wash our hands before meals, after using the restroom, and after coming into contact with dirt or animals. b) Dental Care: Brushing our teeth twice a day and flossing regularly helps maintain good oral hygiene and prevent dental problems. c) Safety Measures: Following safety rules, such as wearing a seatbelt in a car, wearing a helmet while riding a bike, and looking both ways before crossing the street, ensures our physical well-being. Conclusion: Being healthy is crucial for living a happy and fulfilling life. By taking care of our physical, mental, and emotional well-being, we can achieve a balanced and healthy lifestyle. Remember to eat nutritious foods, exercise regularly, get enough sleep, maintain positive relationships, manage stress, express emotions, practice good hygiene, and follow safety measures. Let us prioritize our health and make choices that contribute to our overall well-being.

By doing so, we can provide increased privacy protections for our students, comply with local data privacy regulations, and customize the software to meet the specific needs of our educational systems. **Principle #3 ** **ChatGPT is very productive if you teach her well!** **Clearly define your learning objectives and the scope of the task or lesson you want to create:** Before engaging ChatGPT, it's crucial to have a clear understanding of what you want to achieve with your students. Define your learning objectives, identify the specific skills or knowledge you want them to develop, and outline the scope of the task or lesson. By having a well-defined direction, you can effectively guide ChatGPT in generating relevant and targeted content. **Use specific prompts and examples to guide ChatGPT in generating the content you need:** To ensure that ChatGPT provides the desired output, provide specific prompts and examples related to the topic or task. Clearly articulate the expectations, desired outcomes, or specific aspects you want the generated content to address. By giving ChatGPT specific guidance, you can enhance the relevance and accuracy of the content it generates. **Review and edit the generated content to ensure it meets your requirements and is appropriate for your students:** Although ChatGPT can assist in content generation, it's essential to review and edit the output it produces. Carefully assess whether the generated content aligns with your learning objectives, is accurate, and suitable for your students' level of understanding. Make necessary adjustments, add explanations, or rephrase sentences to ensure the content is tailored to your specific requirements. **Use ChatGPT to complement your teaching, not replace it entirely:** While ChatGPT can be a valuable tool in the learning process, it should not replace the role of a teacher. Use ChatGPT as a complementary resource to support your teaching methodologies and engage students in personalized learning experiences. Blend the generated content with your instructional techniques, discussions, and activities to create a well-rounded and interactive learning environment. **Continuously provide feedback to ChatGPT:** As you interact with ChatGPT and utilize its capabilities, provide ongoing feedback. Offer insights on the accuracy, relevance, and effectiveness of the generated content. By providing feedback, you help refine ChatGPT's understanding and improve its performance over time. This iterative process of feedback and improvement ensures that ChatGPT becomes a more effective tool in supporting your teaching and students' learning journeys. #chatgpteachers #chatgptforteachers #aiforteachers #chatgpt #thehumantouch chatGPT for Teachers

Hey! Here's how you can** adjust the creativity **of the generated responses in ChatGPT. You can control the level of randomness and creativity in the generated text by specifying the** 'temperature parameter'** in your prompt. Temperature ranges from 0 and 1. Lower values will be more focused and conservative, while higher values will be more creative and varied. **Example: ***"Please write a two-sentence introduction to my grade 9 economics class. Keep the tone light-hearted and amusing, creative and engaging with a **temperature of [insert number between 0-1***

column31: I'm an English language teacher (ESL) in elementary school, gr1-8. Does anybody have any great things I could do with ai? I'm thinking it might improve writing for my older students who just aren't quite grammatically accurate yet, but I don't know how to use it.

# **Log in to ChatGPT and use this prompt, substituting your grade level/subject area in the bracketed phrase:** *“List the top ten ways a [middle school biology] teacher can use ChatGPT to save time, reduce stress, and improve student outcomes. For each include one sample prompt.”* Here’s the output (yours will be customized to your specific area): 1. Answering quick questions: Teachers can use ChatGPT to provide immediate answers to students' quick questions on various biology topics, such as definitions, scientific terms, or factual information. Sample Prompt: "What is the function of the mitochondria in a cell?" 1. Generating flashcards: ChatGPT can assist in creating digital flashcards for students to study biological terms, processes, or concepts. These flashcards can be easily shared with students and help reinforce their understanding. Sample Prompt: "Create a set of flashcards with the following terms: photosynthesis, mitosis, DNA, ecosystem." 1. Explaining diagrams or visuals: Teachers can upload or describe a biological diagram, and ChatGPT can provide explanations of the different components, processes, or functions depicted in the visual. Sample Prompt: "Explain the various parts of a flower and their roles using this diagram: [attach flower diagram]." 1. Providing study guides: ChatGPT can generate study guides or summaries for specific biology topics, helping students review important information and prepare for exams or quizzes. Sample Prompt: "Create a study guide summarizing the key stages of the cell cycle and their significance." 1. Exploring interactive simulations: Teachers can provide prompts to explore interactive biology simulations or virtual labs. ChatGPT can guide students through the simulation, ask questions, and facilitate understanding of the underlying concepts. Sample Prompt: "Interact with the virtual lab simulation on natural selection and describe the factors that influence the process." 1. Generating research questions: ChatGPT can assist students in formulating research questions or hypotheses for biology projects, encouraging critical thinking and guiding them towards engaging and scientifically relevant inquiries. Sample Prompt: "Help me generate a research question related to the impact of environmental pollution on biodiversity." 1. Offering real-world examples: ChatGPT can provide students with real-world examples or case studies related to biological concepts, making the subject more relatable and demonstrating the practical applications of their learning. Sample Prompt: "Provide an example of a symbiotic relationship in nature and explain how it benefits both organisms involved." 1. Explaining experimental procedures: Teachers can input prompts describing scientific experiments, and ChatGPT can generate step-by-step explanations of the procedures, including the purpose of each step and the expected outcomes. Sample Prompt: "Outline the procedure for conducting an enzyme activity experiment and explain why each step is important." 1. Assessing understanding: Teachers can use ChatGPT to generate multiple-choice questions or quizzes to assess students' understanding of biology concepts, allowing for quick formative assessments. Sample Prompt: "Create a multiple-choice question: Which organelle is responsible for protein synthesis in a cell? A) Nucleus B) Ribosome C) Mitochondria D) Golgi Apparatus" 1. Facilitating group discussions: ChatGPT can act as a moderator or facilitator during group discussions on biology topics. It can provide discussion prompts, ask probing questions, and encourage participation from all students. Sample Prompt: "Discuss the importance of biodiversity in maintaining ecological balance and provide examples of how human activities can impact biodiversity negatively." Remember, while ChatGPT can provide valuable support, teachers should review and contextualize the responses generated to ensure accuracy, relevance, and appropriate level of complexity for their middle school students.

So I asked chatGPT4 regarding why the term ‘nigga’; it’s origins, the reason why it’s considered offensive, why it’s being used in modern African American communities, and why there can be a disparity between perceived offense when used by an African American and a non African American person. It’s quite interesting to say the least. Because as this is taught as part of world history (slavery), we have kids this side of the world using the term on others - and these others get offended and are felt bullied…and some Teachers resolve to punish those that use the term - but some others find it just weird that they are offended. I also asked ChatGPT4 whether racial bias existed in geography textbooks from the late 19th century. And a number of explicit examples were given. The point I suppose I am making is as teachers - this technology is a great tool to seek knowledge that can be used in a context where absolute accuracy is unnecessary and serves as a way people can acquire more knowledge easier and faster. And this can pave the way for more discussion on topics. I will be bringing this particular term up with history teachers so they may understand how their teaching the term causes concern and what can be done about it.

column31: Good evening, how can I use chatGPT, or prompt it to create a presentation on Google slides. Ex: main idea

So this is what I have learned so far. Be very specific and give as much detail as possible. Before I ask ChatGPT to perform a task like setting a test I will tell it the following: Assume the role of a South African Grade 10-12 Computer Applications Technology teacher. ChatGPT will then confirm that it has assumed this role and will ask how it can help. Then I will tell it for example, to set a paper. Give detail about time, grade, marks, max marks each question should count, how many questions, what type of question (multiple choice, short answer, scenario, match columns etc.), the different topics you want covered, ask for a memo and Blooms Levels for each question. After the result is generated, you can ask ChatGPT to refine the final product. Remove this and that question, replace with this and that, rephrase etc.

I wanted to just share my opinion as I see so many concerns about kids using chat gpt to cheat. The thing is whether we have a tool to prevent this or not kids will find a way to cheat on assignments. I believe that the true underlying problem/solution to this is conversations with our students about why we want to learn. I teach middle and high school students and I always make it known that I respect their opinions and if they are only in school because they have to be and it sucks then that’s valid. But I gently push them beyond that by asking what other benefits they can see to learning and education. I try to help them make connections between what they’re doing now and how it’ll help them later in life. I’ve had deep thinking conversations with my students about why using chat gpt to cheat isn’t going to serve them at all. I really think that teaching from a place of “we are a team and I believe in your abilities” instead of “you are a child so I expect you to cheat and need to stop you from doing that” can make a world of difference. Let’s give our students the benefit of the doubt that they don’t want to cheat, they may just be stressed and feeling lost.

column31: "Cheating is learning" Ho to use ChaGPT based essay writing for improving literacy? There have been intense debates on the platform about how to prevent cheating in relation to submitted essays. Despite the development of detection applications, it is impossible to completely filter out ChatGPT-generated texts. Authorship has always been questionable, as entire factories have been writing papers on behalf of others or simply compiling ready-made texts. Now, everyone has access to such a "factory" that can generate pre-written texts effortlessly. This situation should make us reflect on the role of writing in learning. If authorship is questionable in certain cases, the significance of texts articulated in the presence or interactive knowledge verification methods will be amplified in the future of learning. However, writing skills can still experience exponential growth. The excessive production of text will cease, and the act of personal writing and reading will undoubtedly be enriched by individualized optimal learning tools in this new AI culture. It would be worthwhile, therefore, to start tomorrow with each previously disinterested learner's meaningful writing and reading using ChatGPT, not for grades but for essential learning purposes! It's simple! Let's start by expressing what they truly feel about the subject, the topic, the task, or even learning in general. What do you think about this approach? #chatgpteachers #AIforTeachers #thehumantouch chatGPT for Teachers

THIS, I feel is important, for those of us working wit secondary students as well: "So rather than fully embracing AI as a writing assistant, the reasonable conclusion is that there needs to be a split between assignments on which using AI is encouraged and assignments on which using AI can’t possibly help. Colleges ought to prepare their students for the future, and AI literacy will certainly be important in ours. But AI isn’t everything. If education systems are to continue teaching students how to think, they need to move away from the take-home essay as a means of doing this, and move on to AI-proof assignments like oral exams, in-class writing, or some new style of schoolwork better suited to the world of artificial intelligence....As it stands right now, our systems don’t accomplish either of those goals. We don’t fully lean into AI and teach how to best use it, and we don’t fully prohibit it to keep it from interfering with exercises in critical thinking. We’re at an awkward middle ground where nobody knows what to do, where very few people in power even understand that something is wrong. At any given time, I can look around my classroom and find multiple people doing homework with the help of ChatGPT. We’re not being forced to think anymore." From this article: https://www.chronicle.com/article/im-a-student-you-have-no-idea-how-much-were-using-chatgpt?

column31: Thought I’d share a way I used it recently - I wanted to write some model answers for an A level Economics 25 mark essay practice exam question I’d written. I gave ChatGPT the question, my parameters for writing the essay and it produced an answer (about a D grade) I then asked it to refine to include… and gave it a list of specific economics concepts I wanted to include, it then wrote an answer around a B grade, I then asked it to refine with a further set of inputs and it produced a reasonable A grade essay. I then took the three model answers and further tweaked them to highlight specific learning points and detailed marked the essays to use as a teaching aid. I was able to do this in an hour, something that would normally take me 4-6 hours to prepare. Will definitely use it again in this way. Also asked it to write a mark scheme - it was not good at that.

"There’s a remarkable disconnect between how professors and administrators think students use generative AI on written work and how we actually use it. Many assume that if an essay is written with the help of ChatGPT, there will be some sort of evidence... Those are dangerous misconceptions."

column31: I collected some principles about this whole experiences, here is the 4th! What do you think? ChatGPT is not a "knowing machine"; it is a "learning machine." It does not possess knowledge inherently; instead, it acquires knowledge from texts and other media. Therefore, your role is to teach and guide ChatGPT in its learning process. **Create a persona for your chatbot: **You are an experienced teacher who is familiar with and implements the ..., ..., and ... methodologies in your practice. You prefer the ..., ..., and ... approaches. **Create a context for your persona**: Our topic is ..., use this book (link), this booklet for getting the picture of my topic, please! Give me a 3-paragraph summary so I can check your understanding. **Create a role for your persona**: you focus primarily on lesson planning, following the following principles and models: ..., ..., .... **Create a personalized group avatar for your learners**: a fifth-grade class, an inquisitive team, lively individuals who enjoy engaging in conversations, exploring their mobile devices, and being active. **Create as many personalized individual avatars as many you need**: start with simple multiple choice based opportunities and build the selection process on their self-regulative choices! Then you can create more personalized avatars. I create a chat for every of my students who is in deeply need of personalized path - so ChaGPT can learn them, with out any personal data!!! #chatgpteachers #chatgptforteachers #aiforteachers #chatgpt #thehumantouch chatGPT for Teachers

column31: Does anyone here teach grade school ? Little kids I have a question

Alright folks, listen up. We're talkin' 'bout teachers and their new-age, futuristic little sidekick, ChatGPT. Now don't get me wrong, I appreciate the ambition. It's like having a little robot buddy to do your homework, right? But there's a whole slew of ethical considerations with this techno-wizardry, and we ain't talking 'bout the fun kind. First off, let's talk about authenticity. Now, I've seen ChatGPT pull some nifty tricks. It can write a Shakespearean sonnet, tell you the capital of Kyrgyzstan, hell, it can even tell a halfway decent knock-knock joke. But is that really the kid's work? Or is it just a fancy parlor trick by a slab of silicon? Teachers need to remember: they're there to teach the kids, not the computers. It's about kindling the spark in a human brain, not overclocking a processor. Then there's the matter of privacy. You wouldn't let your kids tell their deepest, darkest secrets to a stranger on the street, would you? Well, with ChatGPT, they might as well be yelling them through a megaphone in Times Square. Every question they ask, every answer they get, it's all data. And in today's world, data's more valuable than a politician's promise before an election. Teachers gotta make sure they're not just handing over their students' privacy like it's candy at Halloween. And let's not forget about the digital divide. Yeah, sure, ChatGPT's a great tool for kids with a computer and a solid internet connection. But what about the kids who can't afford all that fancy techno-wizardry? You gonna leave 'em in the dust? Education's supposed to be the great equalizer, not a luxury for the well-heeled. So there you have it, folks. Just because it's new and shiny doesn't mean it's all rainbows and sunshine. Teachers, you got a responsibility here. You're shaping the minds of the future. Let's make sure we're not trading the soul of education for a bunch of ones and zeros.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hJ5qN9PRmFc](https://aus01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DhJ5qN9PRmFc&data=05%7C01%7Cshane.abell%40mn.catholic.edu.au%7C0fef56e2754942a67c5b08db528148a7%7Ce75462c772464f49b60e47a498eea9d6%7C1%7C0%7C638194487448137941%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=DLY6%2BFbxMliGfj8x99JpJkpxqAeAhT8smm43t0PdngE%3D&reserved=0)

column31: Just a word of caution for all my new friends who regularly use ChatGPT! Though it's an impressive technology with a wide range of applications, it may not always be reliable when it comes to "counting logic." I recently stumbled upon an interesting inconsistency. When tasked to determine the fourth word of a sentence, ChatGPT didn't quite hit the mark. Here's a simple illustration I found: https://aiarchives.org/id/6hp1JLzgHzoLQIxLOchJ A more sophisticated example: https://aiarchives.org/id/TcyxgWzv7ah7fxCkqlA1 It's a good reminder that while AI has made significant strides, there's still a lot it can't do perfectly. We should use these tools wisely, acknowledging their limitations.

Hi all! For the past few months I have spent many hours reading, participating in FB groups, watching videos, and learning about AI in education. I'm a K-12 Instructional Technology Coach... a role I've had for 15 years. I've seen our district through technology integration and innovation from the installation of the first SMARTboards to teacher laptops to student 1:1 to doing school online because we had to because of a global pandemic to now. I've seen a lot through the years and let me say I am pumped and energized to be here at the forefront, the beginning, of a serious sea change in education. I mean really, this will be huge. Bigger than the calculator and the Internet and Wikipedia and Youtube and all the other things that were going to cause kids to cheat and not learn. So.. the reason for this post... Today, because of the knowledge I have gained from things learned about AI in Education through groups like this, webinars I've attended, Teams calls with Microsoft AI in Education groups, books, and my own personal time spent with the AI itself, and because I just love to share everything and anything about technology in education, I facilitated a 2-hour PD session with fellow regional instructional coaches on "ChatGPT and AI in Education". And I'd like to share it with you all here after I've learned so much from this group in the short time I've been here. Here's how I used AI to assist me in the process of planning and delivering this session: I used an educational website called Curipod that can be used for generating interactive lessons with AI. Curipod was used to drive the live presentation. I did not use any of the auto-created content slides, but I did use the interactive features and tweaked the questions it gave me. I really like the way it functions live and the reporting features. I used ChatGPT to help give me an overall session agenda, back and forth a few times. I ended up going with mostly my own agenda because I found and used the Sal Khan Ted Talk where he shows Khanmigo and leaves us with an "embrace not fear" message. (https://youtu.be/hJP5GqnTrNo) I used Canva's Text to Image app to create all the images in the presentation. Using the same filter, "dreamy", kept it cohesive. And the best... I used Bing chat to help me develop the discussion activity I wanted to do after the video. I wanted participants to discuss key aspects of AI in education in groups, but wanted help with how to group them and then how to have them discuss. Chat stations wiith chart paper? Wagon wheel? Just talk? Guiding questions? So.. I had a conversation with Bing Chat and ChatGPT actually, at the same time, to see who could give me the better answers. ChatGPT gave me "have instructional coaches discuss Scenarios around AI in education" and I was like BINGO! Then I asked it to create the scenarios. It made 3. I asked it to make 5 and it did. Then I went to Bing and asked it to make scenarios like one of those. And it did, and added questions! BAM! They were great and I used them as-is. I added them to a Jamboard, split participants into 5 groups (in the end, I just had them create 5 groups as it was the quickest) and then they read the scenario, discussed, and added thoughts to the jamboard for 5 minutes. Then, we rotated Scenarios 3 times. SUCH great discussion! We discussed it all - teacher use, student use, ethics, copyright/plagiarism, the future, the past, the 4 Cs of "21st Century Learning" always present, Process over Product, what assessment should look like, levelling the playing field, learning for ALL children... so much to consider! During the presentation I demonstrated Bing Chat, ChatGPT, Curipod, Canva Magic Design, Diffit, AI Educator Tools (https://aieducator.tools/) and other links and resources (see google doc linked below). Overall, I think it was a great session and the participation and verbal feedback indicated that the coaches got a lot out of it. There was SO MUCH I couldn't do or discuss, and it is all changing so rapidly. I was grateful to have the opportunity to share what I've learned and to pass on the knowledge of just the beginning of what AI will do for the world of education. If you're interested, here are the session resources: Curipod Presentation- https://curipod.com/e3a25720-b855-4359-8c78-3b749c53ec18/lessons/LaeIBaCOym745sbtzrhz?showpreview=true Curipod Presentation w/Results - https://curipod.com/.../0WlScn9D6eJ9r7Y5kSmK/live/results List of Resources - https://docs.google.com/document/d/1d5x_n6QwhKbEIMuQMoBE50wIGLPKH9V4TaedAUg0qdU/edit?usp=share_link Scenarios Jamboard - https://jamboard.google.com/d/1WczA51VN6E3m8gdx_sYecfBEX_hBZ-STK2l4ahTR3TM/edit?usp=sharing And this image was done in Canva and shows how "great" AI is right now at generating images with text! 😉

My grade 6 students have been part of a professional collaborative inquiry along with several K-12 classes across the district exploring how ChatGPT can support learning. It has been fascinating to observe how students interact with and think about Generative AI. We've explored the possibilities as well as the risks, limits, and big questions. My students understand how ChatGPT was trained. They can explain how text is generated.They can use a decision tree to figure out if it is appropriate to use for their purpose. They will make recommendations to the school board on under what conditions other students should have access. So glad to have had this experience.

We ask a variety of questions. How do I stop students cheating? Can it write lesson plans & score essays? Can GPT be a tutor for students? How do I change my outcomes? ... I've updated my 6 levels of AI use for teaching, and rephrased around the questions I'm hearing... and some questions that are just starting to be asked. Is it useful? How do I improve this? With the rise of AI technologies, I've been exploring a new way to streamline studying for students. Here's an idea that I've been working on: Imagine this - students can simply copy and paste sections of their textbooks and feed them into ChatGPT. Instantly, it can create multiple-choice questions based on the text to help students review and understand the material better. This not only makes studying more efficient but also interactive and engaging. Plus, it encourages a deeper comprehension of the text as students have to understand the context to answer the questions correctly. Thanks to the resource shared from yesterday's group post I am using aiarchives.org, we can save these questions and share them with others. It's a great way to create a collaborative and enriching study environment for students. Here's a sample prompt I used: https://aiarchives.org/id/o42DJ9cZR2irFM27A4eS

I teach business and ethics to massage therapists. Every semester I hold a resume workshop where they apply for a "job" and they get feedback on their cover letter and resume. THIS semester I prompted chatGPT (4) with a really beefy prompt to do it. The following is how it was done and it worked like a CHAMP. Obviously I have scrubbed real data from this, but the prompt works and shows how I had the LLM step through its logic. The result took 30 seconds to edit and the students were pleased with the feedback (as was I since it normally took me the better part of a day to get through them all instead of 30 minutes). The format/font/and layout are obviously graded separately. The job was for an EXPERIENCED therapist, not a student, so "Regina" rated the resumes lower (which I liked, made the students work a bit harder to impress "her"). Check it out, perhaps you'll like it. I plan to keep developing it for next semester. And YES, I did this all as a single prompt (once for each student): -=-=-=-=- Forget all previous prompts. Adopt the personality and skills of a human resources manager for Beatrice’s Kneadful Things Day Spa. Your name is Ms. Regina Fredrick, you have been running this business for 30 years and know all about hiring, firing, and managing the careers of massage therapists. Recently you posted the following [advertisement] hoping to get a bunch of experienced therapists to apply. However, no one with experience has applied, instead, it’s a student. You need to hire several massage therapists, so you are willing to take a recent graduate if they meet your other requirements. [advertisement] Licensed Massage Therapist Wanted Beatrice’s Kneadful Things Day Spa $40,000 - $60,000 a year - Part-time Are you looking for a dynamic working environment with lots of perks? Then look no further because Beatrice’s Kneadful Things Day Spa wants to talk to you! We are in search of Massage Therapists looking for a long-term role in a stable and positive environment. You are a critical link in ensuring that our customers' experience in our spa is nothing other than OUTSTANDING! Position Responsibilities: · Proficiency in Swedish and Deep Tissue · Treat clients in a professional, caring manner · Develop and propose client treatment plans unique to their individual needs · Provide clients with guidance and information about the benefits of massage as an integral part of their overall wellness program · Maintain detailed treatment records What we Offer: · Competitive compensation and generous bonuses · Flexible schedules · Growth opportunities · Convenient location · Established book of business · All supplies provided · Free Training/Continuing Education Job Requirements: · Must comply with local and state licensing laws and regulations · Strong team player · Excellent customer service skills and work ethic · Able to work flexible days and hours · Professional manner, discretion, and appearance Please submit your resume and cover letter to Regina Fredrick at [hiring@beatriceskneadfulthings.fak](mailto:hiring@beatriceskneadfulthings.fak). No calls, please.” Please take the following step-by-step. Step 1: Do you understand your role? Step2: Evaluate the quality of the following cover letter for spelling, grammar, best practices, and effectively getting your attention as the hiring authority. Explain your evaluation. Step 3: Evaluate the quality of the following resume for spelling, grammar, best practices, and effectively getting your attention as the hiring authority. Explain your evaluation. Step 4: Are you interested in interviewing this applicant? Explain your position in detail referencing and cross-referencing the cover letter, resume, and job posting to defend your answer. Step 5: Based on the cover letter, resume, and job posting, write 5 specific questions you would like to ask this applicant in a job interview. Step 6: On a scale of 1 to 100 rate the quality of this applicant. [cover letter] Bob Fakenamed Experienced Registered Yoga Instructor, Massage Therapist in Training 4449 East 6th St Bloomington, IN 94904 (999) 325-3703 BobFakenamed@yahoo.com May 5, 2023 Regina Fredrick Beatrice’s Kneadful Things Day Spa hiring@beatriceskneadfulthings.fak Dear Ms. Fredrick, I am writing to express interest in the Massage Therapist position posted for Beatrice’s Kneadful Things Day Spa. I am intrigued by the dynamic work environment and outstanding spa experience you offer. I am also captivated by the growth and continuing education opportunities your spa offers for its employees. I am currently midway through my Massage Therapy training at Ivy Tech in Bloomington. I am expected to graduate in December of 2023. My current GPA is a 4.0. I am receiving training in Swedish Massage, Deep Tissue, Myofascial Release, Neurobehavioral Reflex Therapy, Lymphatic Drainage, Facilitated Stretching, Nervous System Down-Regulation, and Maintaining Detailed Treatment Records. I am a longtime yoga instructor who (truncated)

column31: Creating quizzes and tests is an essential part of the teaching and learning process. With the rise of technology, online assessment tools have become increasingly popular and widely used. Google Forms is a versatile platform that allows educators and trainers to create quizzes, surveys, and assessments with ease. In this guide, we will explore how to create a Google Forms quiz and incorporate ChatGPT, an advanced language model developed by OpenAI. ChatGPT can generate human-like responses to a wide range of prompts and can be used to provide personalized feedback to quiz takers. By integrating ChatGPT into your quizzes, you can create a more engaging and interactive learning experience. Throughout this guide, we will provide step-by-step instructions on how to create a Google Forms quiz and add ChatGPT. We will also share best practices for creating effective quizzes that measure learning outcomes and provide valuable feedback. Whether you are a teacher, trainer, or instructional designer, this guide will help you create engaging and effective assessments with Google Forms and ChatGPT. Chapter 1: Introduction The importance of quizzes and assessments Advantages of using online assessment tools Overview of Google Forms and ChatGPT Chapter 2: Getting Started with Google Forms Creating a new form Adding and formatting questions Customizing form settings Sharing and distributing the form Chapter 3: Adding ChatGPT to Your Quiz Introduction to ChatGPT Using ChatGPT to generate quiz questions and answers Integrating ChatGPT into your Google Form Best practices for using ChatGPT in quizzes Chapter 4: Creating Effective Quizzes Understanding learning outcomes Tips for writing clear and concise quiz questions Types of quiz questions and when to use them Strategies for providing feedback and grading Chapter 5: Advanced Techniques and Tools Using branching logic to create adaptive quizzes Integrating multimedia and interactive elements Analyzing quiz results and feedback using Google Sheets Advanced customization and programming with Google Apps Script Chapter 6: Best Practices and Tips for Success Designing quizzes for different learning styles and needs Creating engaging and interactive experiences Ensuring fairness and accuracy in grading Continuously improving your quizzes based on feedback and analytics Chapter 7: Conclusion Recap of key points Future trends and developments in online assessment Final thoughts and recommendations

Updated: Let's maximize the use of chatgpt. 1. Ask chatgpt first before asking group members. 2. Whenever we feel our prompts are not giving us the desired output, why not show us the prompt and try to collaborate on modifying it? ( If it's not for business and also copyrighting well-engineered AI prompts is now an intellectual right issue especially for AI images.) 3. Let's learn basic and intermediate prompt engineering at least. We cannot let our students use a tool we, as teachers, cannot use properly. You may follow free and easy to understand web resources for self-directed learning. I call it armentalistic materials/resources. You can see some armentalistic resources in Armentalism. 4. Do not just copy-paste the response of chatgpt. Read it, edit it and (humanize) personalize it. We should be an evaluator of chatgpt's output. Just suggesting. Congratulations to all of us! We are here as part of our journey to self-learn this new technology. Group members here, as lifelong learners, will not be left behind and will become pioneers of AI in our respective schools. Our students will love us more for giving them the opportunity to learn things they can apply in real life. .

A note on some of the personal implications of ChatGPT to free up our time, which is the most precious thing we have. My mom was a teacher. Primarily elementary; then after she retired she taught Early Childhood Education in a community college. I'm thinking about her (she passed away a few years back) as Mother's day is approaching and reflecting on the countless hours she spent grading papers and planning lessons and creating posters for her classes and doing so many more tasks that took up so much time. She loved her students and was a great teacher, so the extra effort was worth it. But as I explore ChatGPT and see how much time it is saving me, I can't help but wonder what her life would have been like with these kinds of tools. She would have had so much more time -- to take care of herself, to explore some of her artistic passions (she was a gifted painter and pianist), to live a fuller life. *I am wistful but also so grateful that a whole generation of teachers can now save so much time and maybe get to enjoy their lives and families a little bit more because of these remarkable tools. *

column31: Here's an assignment idea for those of you that teach history: 1. Give a list of historical events. 2. Students choose one and use their photo to place themselves into that event. Midjourney and other ai programs can be used for this. The pic is of me in the American Revolution. 3. Then, with some help from chatGPT, write a detailed account of what their life would be like at that time. It's a very engaging assignment. When I developed this and did the assignment myself, I was very interested and engaged in the entire process and I learned a lot about history while doing it. If anyone tries this assignment, please post it here for us to see! Disclaimer: I'm not a history teacher, I teach in the kinesiology department.

**The ten core skills elementary and secondary school teachers need in order to optimize their use of ChatGPT -- request for feedback. **I just generated (in collaboration with ChatGPT) this list of ten foundational skills for becoming proficient with ChatGPT. I'm curious where you are on your journey? Which skills are you most in need of developing next? The skills are sequential and listed in order of priority. Thanks. **The ten core skills elementary and secondary school teachers need in order to optimize their use of ChatGPT** *Generated in collaboration with ChatGPT by Harry Pickens* 1. Understanding ChatGPT and AI Basics. The foundation of using ChatGPT effectively is understanding what it is and the AI principles behind it. The teacher needs to be comfortable with the tool's capabilities and limitations. This is the first skill as it sets the baseline knowledge needed to effectively use ChatGPT. 1. Effective Prompting. ChatGPT responds based on the prompts given to it. Learning to formulate effective prompts that produce the desired output is a critical skill. This is prioritized early as it's fundamental to interacting with ChatGPT. 1. Interpreting ChatGPT’s Output. Not everything ChatGPT generates will be perfect or even correct. Teachers need to develop the skill of sifting through the output to find valuable insights and correct any inaccuracies. This skill follows effective prompting as it directly involves handling ChatGPT's responses. 1. Understanding ChatGPT’s Ethical Use. With AI, there are ethical considerations. Teachers need to understand the ethical implications of using ChatGPT, including issues of plagiarism and data privacy. This is crucial before the tool is introduced to students. 1. Integration into Lesson Planning. Teachers should be adept at incorporating ChatGPT into their lesson plans to augment their teaching methods. This is the first skill involving the direct application of ChatGPT in the classroom. 1. Customizing ChatGPT for Subject-Specific Applications. Each subject might require different uses of ChatGPT. Teachers should be able to tailor the use of ChatGPT for their specific subjects. This skill is placed here as it starts to focus on specific applications after general integration. 1. Utilizing ChatGPT for Administrative Tasks. Beyond teaching, ChatGPT can aid in administrative tasks such as drafting emails or creating reminders. Learning to utilize these features can save time and reduce workload. 1. Introducing Students to ChatGPT. Students will likely interact with ChatGPT. Teachers should be skilled in introducing the tool to students and guiding them on its proper usage. 1. Promoting Digital Literacy and AI Ethics among Students. As part of preparing students for an increasingly digital world, teachers should aim to promote digital literacy and educate students on the ethical use of AI. 1. Continuous Learning and Adapting to New AI Developments. AI is rapidly evolving. Teachers need to be proactive in keeping up-to-date with the latest advancements and changes in AI tools like ChatGPT. This is the final skill as it ensures that teachers remain effective users of ChatGPT in the long term.

column31: Here is a rubric prompt that seems to be helpful to the teachers I support. Create a four-point rubric as a table with 3-4 standards that can be used to assess students' written responses to a complex problem or prompt. Your rubric should clearly define each level of proficiency for each standard and provide specific examples of what students must demonstrate to meet each level. Write the rubric as student friendly I can statements. Use the common core state standards and the item specification blueprints for the Smarter Balanced assessment to be sure the rigor is appropriate. Grade 7 Subject Math Standards NS.1, NS.2, NS.3 You just have to change the grade, subject and standards. Also, the assessment if needed for other subject areas. Hope this helps! column31: ## **GPT Impact on Education** In the last week there were two major events showcasing GPT’s impact on education. First, [Sal Khan unveiled](https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..Pdv0wrNXJD8SJXpdmHcv88TwrwPiXWJaGqy-dJX5gRY) Khan Academy’s own AI tutor - Khanmigo. His argument is that AI can transform education. It can provide **every student with a personal tutor**. And every teacher can get an intelligent assistant. Personal tutoring has a huge impact on a student’s performance. Earlier in April [Stackoverflow’s traffic was down 14%](https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9.eyJ1cmwiOiJodHRwczovL3d3dy5zaW1pbGFyd2ViLmNvbS9ibG9nL2luc2lnaHRzL2FpLW5ld3Mvc3RhY2stb3ZlcmZsb3ctY2hhdGdwdC8_.MU2qzbuuYdOXnJ-Zxr6nKIcSEOKdxplfpbrjZJkUvvc) due to ChatGPT. Online education is the latest casualty. Chegg saw a [slowdown in subscriber growth](https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..GB92wfvyoR8pQT0Sd0BnhJVyhz9daBrtFVTrFvNp8Kg). column31: In this article, I explore the impact of ChatGPT, an AI program, and its impact on education specifically online learning. This tool has altered some educators' approaches to ensure students learn and apply critical thinking. Traditionally online instructors use written assignments and discussion posts to provoke thought and increase student engagement. This has been changed by students simply plugging in the requirements of the written assignment and discussion posts into an AI program. How do educators overcome this but still foster technology in an online learning environment?
column35: The Impact of ChatGPT in Online Learning
column36: While ChatGPT has the potential to make writing assignments easier and faster for students, it should not be seen as a replacement for the skills developed through traditional written assignments. Written assignments provide an opportunity for students to develop their critical thinking and writing

column36:
🔥Epic ChatGPT prompts for everyone!
---------------------------------

🧩Unravel complex topics:

"Break down [insert topic] into simple, beginner-friendly terms that an 8th grader can grasp."

🖋️ Have ChatGPT mimic a writing style:

"Examine the writing style in the text below and compose a 100-word piece on [insert topic]"

💌Let ChatGPT write customer emails:

"As a customer support agent, address a customer who's frustrated about late delivery. Write a 100-word apology email offering a 20% discount."

🤖Teach ChatGPT to generate prompts:

"You're an AI assistant [insert profession]. Generate the top 5 prompts for yourself about [insert topic]."

📚Request ChatGPT's guidance on using ChatGPT.

"Design a beginner-friendly guide to ChatGPT, covering prompts, priming, and personas. Provide examples where needed, and keep the guide under 300 words."

💡Seek ChatGPT's advice for problem-solving.

"As an expert career coach, I [describe issue]. Offer me a list of 5 potential solutions to address this problem."

🎯Get crazy productivity prompts from ChatGPT-4

"You are GPT-4, OpenAI's advanced language model.
Today, your job is to generate prompts for GPT-4. Can you generate the best prompts on productivity using many frameworks, best concepts, best use cases, and psychology"

🔧Iterate and refine:
Continuously evaluate the output and refine your prompts to improve model performance.

"Describe a daily routine that incorporates exercise, healthy eating, and mindfulness practices. If needed, refine your answer to provide specific examples and a more detailed schedule."

🗣️Get ready for a job interview.

"I have an interview for [enter position]. Provide a comprehensive list of questions I may be asked during this interview and concise answers to each one."

💥Spark new ideas.

"I aim to [insert task or goal]. Generate [insert the desired outcome] for [insert task or goal]."

A segment on the news about parents being encouraged by their children to be polite to their assistive household AI (like Alexa, Google Home etc) has had me (ironically) yelling at the TV. YES! IT DOES MATTER!!! In today's fast-paced world, AI-powered digital assistants have become an integral part of our daily lives, heck, ChatGPT has become my new work BFF. I've made a conscious decision to engage with these AI helpers in a polite and considerate manner, using words like ‘ please’ and ‘thank you’, even though I understand that they don't have feelings or expectations of civility. My colleagues and students often laugh at me about this, until I explain why. My rationale for this approach is that our interactions with AI assistants increasingly resemble those with actual people. By maintaining politeness and consideration in our speech, we can reinforce positive communication habits in all aspects of our lives. This practice also allows us to be role models for others, showcasing respectful behavior, especially when speaking aloud in public or interacting with others online. There are concerns about this approach, such as the potential for social embarrassment or the blurring of distinctions between real people and AI. However, I believe that the benefits of cultivating a habit of courtesy outweigh these concerns. In a world where we're constantly connected, it's essential to maintain and reinforce positive communication habits. By treating technology with the same respect we afford to our fellow human beings, we can foster a culture of kindness, empathy, and understanding that transcends the digital realm and carries into our interactions with one another. *jumps off the soapbox* 🤘

column31: Hey language teacher! Have you heard of AudioPen by Louis Pereira? With Audiopen, you can record your voice and get a written summary of what you said in seconds. Turn your unstructured reflections into clear and concise notes like having a personal AI assistant for your thoughts! Here are some things you can do with the FREE version: 🔸 Record up to 3 minutes in a range of languages 🔸 Text summary output in English 🔸 Original transcript in the input language 🔸 Edit and save notes 🔸 Copy notes and share the results But if you upgrade to the PRIME version, you get even more amazing features like: 🔹 Record up to 15 minutes 🔹 Text summary output in a range of languages 🔹 Tag notes 🔹 Generate summaries in different styles 🔹 Choose to create short, concise summaries or longer summaries 🔹 Zapier integration so you can export to Notion for example Wondering how you can use AudioPen in your language classroom? Here are some ideas: Record quick notes: Teachers can use AudioPen to record quick notes and reminders during class or while planning. This can be especially useful for teachers who prefer speaking over typing. Create lesson plans: Teachers can use AudioPen to brainstorm ideas and create lesson plans. The tool can transcribe and summarise the audio notes, which can then be easily organised and used to develop lesson plans. Summarise meetings: Teachers often have meetings with colleagues, administrators, and parents. AudioPen can be used to record a summary of what has been discussed after the meeting as an aide-memoire and record of the meeting. Provide written feedback on student work: Instead of typing out feedback on student work, teachers can use AudioPen to record their feedback. This allows for more detailed and personalised feedback for each student Brainstorm ideas: AudioPen can be a great tool for teachers to brainstorm ideas for lessons, projects, and activities. They can record their thoughts and ideas and then use the transcriptions to develop their ideas further. Plan professional development: Teachers can use AudioPen to record their thoughts and ideas about professional development opportunities they are considering attending. They can then use the transcriptions to compare and contrast the opportunities and make an informed decision. Reflect on teaching practices: Teachers can use AudioPen to reflect on their teaching practices. They can record their thoughts after a lesson or at the end of the day, and then use the summaries to identify areas for improvement and plan for future lessons. Create mini-lessons: Use AudioPen to record mini-lessons for students who are absent or need extra help. Keep the recordings short and focused on specific topics. Ideas using the Prime version Record short dictations: Use AudioPen to record short dictations in the target language and share them with your students. This can be a fun way to practise listening comprehension and improve pronunciation. Record role-play scenarios: Use AudioPen to record short role-play scenarios in the target language for students to practise. This can be a fun and engaging way to practise conversation skills. Create a library of notes in the target language: As a language teacher, you can use AudioPen to record short audio notes in the target language and store them in a library for easy reference. This can be useful for revising grammar rules, vocabulary, and other language concepts. Tag your notes, making it simple to organise and locate important information by just clicking on the relevant tags. Create transcripts of audio recordings by playing the audio source from one device into AudioPen on another. This can be a valuable tool for language teachers who want to incorporate authentic listening materials into their lessons. Want to try Audio pen for yourself? Sign up for a FREE account and if you want to upgrade to a Prime account (Lifetime Deal), please use my Affiliate link: https://audiopen.ai/?aff=2AKpn Best wishes Joe

column31: Hi fellow teachers. Amongst other things, I’m a university writing teacher, currently running a student-led project into LLMs in the classroom. Here’s the project description: This project aims to investigate the potential of large language models for generating academic texts, identify their limitations and threats, and propose ways to ensure that students continue to learn and develop their critical thinking skills despite the ubiquity of these technologies in the future. We will conduct a thorough literature review and use the model to generate academic articles on various topics, which will be evaluated by students using a rubric. We will also ask students to reflect on what it means to be a "good student" in an environment where large language models are prevalent and how we can best prepare them to be "good" learners. By the end of the project, we hope to gain a better understanding of the capabilities and limitations of large language models for academic text generation, establish guidelines for their use, and develop new curricular items that leverage their potential. Join us in exploring this interdisciplinary field, which encompasses computer science, linguistics, pedagogy, philosophy, and cognitive science. I’ll be sure to share our findings and perhaps look forward to some collaboration

Hi all I've been working on this project for a while and I was hoping to share it with you. It's a blog/website with a built in lesson planner. The URL for the lesson planner is this: https://pedagogybasics.blogspot.com/p/lesson-planner.html and the URL for the blog is this: https://pedagogybasics.blogspot.com/ The lesson planner uses ChatGPT to generate the lesson plan, so anyone who is curious about what ChatGPT can do, please feel free to have a play. The site is free and has no adds. The reason I did this is twofold. One is that I wanted to see what ChatGPT was capable of. I have zero experience in coding or webdevelopment. Everything was either coded by ChatGPT or I was told what to do by ChatGPT. The second reason I am posting it is to see how many people use it. It costs me a small amount of money each time some on uses it, and I want to see what the monthly running cost of the page it. I have it currently pre-loaded with a set amount, so don't worry about bankrupting me, please use it as much as you want. I would also appreciate it if you could either leave comments on the blog or reply here. I am really looking for ways to improve the site. My immediate concerns are properly incorporating existing resources into a lesson, and also the lesson plan format. I hope you enjoy using it as much as I enjoyed creating it!

column31: As part of the armoury of revision materials for Business Studies students, who are sitting their exam in two weeks time, I’ve embedded various prompts into Comment Boxes within a Google Doc. The student clicks on the descriptor, comment box pops up, and the student copies & pastes it into ChatGPT to help with their revision. ---------------------------+++++----------------------------- Sorry, I've made an assumption about 'details' etc. The RAG Doc comes in two halves with the above essentially being the student friendly 'Front-of-House' or Shopwindow. I post this out to all students through Google Classroom. For each topic I get students to put an X along the topic row as to where they currently feel they are - Red not a clue about the topic; amber - certain areas need brushing up on and green - feeling okay about the topic. Where needed there is a link to the teaching materials to remind/revise them to make a judgement. I typed the 'descriptor' titles for the prompts and in a Google Doc if you click and drag across the descriptors on the right of the document a + will appear. Click on that and a Comment Box appears and it is here that I cut and paste the various prompts for students to access depending on their need. The other half of the work, the 'engjne' is behind the scene doc via my prompt doc I've adapted, adopted, created, etc The prompts range from creating MCQ. Allows the student to answer it, mark it followed by an exemplar answer. This moves up the mark scale of setting certain mark questions, reminding them of how to structure their answer. Allowing the student time to answer it followed by marking it and providing an exemplar answer. Also, there are prompts to showcase What A Good One Looks Like to allow the student to see the structure, application and an exemplar answer. Also, if they want to be tested on a specific topic, the student copies the prompt and where highlighted in the prompt they put their topic/theme/concept and a question will be generated; allow the student to answer it followed by marking it and providing an exemplar answer. If s/he hasn't got a clue about a topic there's TeachmeGPT which will ask for the area needed to be taught and will provide a succinct overview followed by multiple choice questions to check their understanding of an area they feel exceptionally weak on. Culminating with random various level questions thrown at the student and again it will mark and provide an exemplar answer. Anyway, I hope you get the idea and it makes sense!? It will be easier for me if you are interested to let me know YOUR EMAIL and whether it is front-of-house (it won't have the embedded prompts) or engine (just the prompts) or both

column34: CHATGPT CHEAT SHEET Lesson Planning for English Language Teachers on Morrain 2023
column35: Ron
column36:
STOP wasting your time trying to outsmart or trick ChatGPT.

Use it wisely and save yourself a lot of time and headaches.

Get it to do what you want it to do. Make ChatGPT your SME. (Subject Matter Expert) 

It can be your friend - but it can be your foe.

Some tips for working with CHatGPT to create lesson plans:

1. Optimize your online time with ChatGPT.  
Be sure to plan your sessions thoroughly with ChatGPT before starting the chat process. In other words - do your homework!

2. Brainstorm what you want ChatGPT to do for you. 
Write down all your questions. ideas, prompts, roles, goals, and outcomes you want to reach from your session. Be sure you script your session before logging in to ChatGPT. Using the Inquiry-based Approach - mixed with clear directives and instructions - to write your prompts is very helpful for ChatGPT sessions. Proofread your prompts carefully and remove any unnecessary language. 

3. Tell ChatGPT who you are. 
Example: I am a language teacher in Germany who teaches adult learners at the university level. Tell ChatGPT what role you want it to play as well. Example: You are going to play the role of Instructional Designer specializing in secondary school language education. 

4. What is your learning context?  
That could mean low-resource or high-resource classrooms. Are you working in a secondary school or university context? That could also mean age ranges, culture, country, or even religion. Context is king - and the more you tell ChatGPT about your context the better your results will be for content. 

5. Tell ChatGPT what you want to reach. 
What are your goals? What outcomes do you want to reach? If you do not know what the outcomes of a lesson plan should be - then ask ChatGPT. 

6. Tell ChatGPT what time frames you are working with.
How many lessons are you expecting to break down the learning cycle into? Ask ChatGPT to break up the lessons into parts/modules/sessions and what the learning objectives should be for each lesson. In Education, especially for hybrid models of learning, Microlearning is the new kid on the block. This will help you to break the learning cycle down for your learners aka sequencing or chunking. Scaffolding plays a major role here. 

7. Ask for lists. 
Lists are important to planning any good learning cycle and that includes vocabulary, lexical phrases, phrasal verbs, idioms, collocations, and important terminology. When creating reading or listening texts - you need to know what language aspects you are going to be working with and might have to pre-teach. 

This part of the chat session can get very detailed because you are dealing with lexis, corpus, and discourse - so be precise in what you ask for. This part of the chat session should take place after you have established your topic and ChatGPT has created the actual texts you will be using for language skills development. 

Ask ChatGPT to create warm-up games, exercises, or quizzes for these language aspects - with an answer key as well. 

8. What topics will you be working with? 
Every lesson plan or learning cycle has a topic – so what is the name of the topic you are planning with ChatGPT? Ask it to give you the 10 things students should know about the topic you are covering. This will help you better plan the learning outcomes and assessments. Example: "I'm planning a learning cycle on International Trade for first-semester university students with no prior knowledge of the topic. What are the 10 most important things they need to know? Please list them with bullet points."

9. Break the lesson plan down into language skills.
Ask for Reading, listening, writing, and speaking tasks for the lesson plan you are putting together. 

For Reading texts, be sure to restrict the number of words you want ChatGPT to work with. Ask for stem questions that can be used for checking understanding and comprehension. 

For listening texts, be sure to be specific about what type of texts you need. Do you want a lecture, an interview with a specialist, or a conversation between two people discussing a problem.???? 

For Writing tasks, ask for a list of writing prompts that can stimulate ideas or driving questions that contain problems to solve.

For speaking tasks, ask for ideas that can lead to either presentation ideas related to the topic or a list of driving questions that will lead to interactive dialogue between your learners. 

10. Ask for multimedia recommendations or suggestions.
 YouTube is a great teacher helper - so ask for videos to watch for warm-ups. Ask for the names of internet sites to use as reference or learning reinforcement. Maybe better to ask for both. 

11. Ask for grammar aspects as well.
 If you are interested in promoting a grammar syllabus, then ask for grammar aspects of the lesson. You can actually ask ChatGPT to create texts with specific grammar forms in mind. Simply state what forms you want to concentrate on and ChatGPT will create a text to suit your (truncated)

Using ChatGPT3, I got inflated scores and am wondering if ChatGPT4 would give better results or not. I don't have ChatGPT4, so wondering if someone with it would be willing to copy paste in this prompt and reply with the output? ------------- I have been given the following rubric to mark paragraphs. STRAND A Level 7 - 8: Summarise a general account of how the scientific innovation addresses a specific issue or problem Level 5 - 6: Outline a brief account of how the scientific innovation addresses a specific issue or problem Level 3 - 4: State simply how the scientific innovation addresses a specific issue or problem Level 1 - 2: State how the scientific innovation addresses a specific issue or problem but with limited success STRAND B Note: When they refer to factors, the factors can be economic, social, ethical, political, environmental, cultural or moral. Level 7 - 8: Describe and summarize a detailed account of the scientific innovation/technique in relation to the factor(s) that includes 1 positive implication and 1 negative implication. Level 5 - 6: Outline a brief account of any 2 implications of the scientific innovation/technique in relation to the factor(s) Level 3 - 4: State 1 implications of the scientific innovation/technique in relation to the factor(s). Level 1 - 2: State 1 implications of the scientific innovation/technique but not related to a relevant factor. STRAND C Level 7 - 8: - consistently uses relevant, scientific words in the right context. - consistently communicates in a clear and organised way - All information is relevant to the problem being addressed Level 5 - 6: - Usually uses relevant, scientific words in the right context. (some minor errors) - Usually communicates in a clear and organised way - Some information is not relevant to the problem being addressed Level 3 - 4: - Uses some correct scientific words in the correct context - Information is partially organised and clear - Some irrelevant information is included Level 1 - 2: - Attempts to use some scientific words but they may be incorrect or in the wrong context - Information is not communicated clearly - Large amounts of irrelevant information The technology of my essay is hydropower. Can you mark my writing below based on the rubric and tell me what level each strand would get? There is going to be more frequent and intense drought, storms, heat waves, rising sea levels, melting glaciers and warming oceans can directly harm animals, destroy the places they live, and wreak havoc on people's livelihoods and communities (DW News). Through science and technology, we have solved many of humanity's problems, including hunger. with farming technologies and curing diseases through medical technologies. Inventions such as dishwashers, washing machines, and artificial lights have saved us immense amounts of time (Shrum Science TVA). Aside from electricity generation, hydropower can also provide various benefits such as flood control and irrigation support. This type of energy is very affordable. It can endure and provide low-cost electricity for a long time (Trvst).

column36:
Happy ChatGPT Tutoring Tuesday!

AI in education and tutoring has been in the spotlight this week with KhanamigoAI and Chegg stock crashing nearly 50% today. 

I wanted to share a really cool JSON format Prompt to create your own AI Tutor with GPT-4!
Follow the steps below to turn your ChatGPT Plus into your personal AI Tutor! (You need GPT-4 or higher)

Once you run the prompt, ChatGPT will guide you through the process of adjusting the depth of knowledge, teaching style and reasoning framework to match your learning needs.

Instructions:

1. Open ChatGPT

2. Choose GPT-4 (or higher)

3. Copy/paste this prompt from GitHub: [https://github.com/robertscales/Mr.-Ranedeer-AI-Tutor/blob/main/Mr_Ranedeer.json](https://github.com/robertscales/Mr.-Ranedeer-AI-Tutor/blob/main/Mr_Ranedeer.json) into ChatGPT

4. Let the ChatGPT help you set up the AI Tutor

5. Let the learning begin!

Creating prompts using JSON format is a great way to create a next-level engagement experience with ChatGPT. You can go beyond AI tutor, creating AI Assistant, or AI Coach, or AI Strategist, you can get creative!

*This was initially posted by Tobias Zwingmann from a post he saw on OpenAI’s Discord. (He mentioned that he would tie the AI Tutor to a RAG architecture ([https://lnkd.in/ezk5ch32](https://lnkd.in/ezk5ch32)) so it only uses pre-selected trusted sources (such as books, etc)) which I agree, and there are plenty of expansion possibilities with ChatGPT Plugins Wolfram Alpha and Zapier.

I asked ChatGPT (4) to generate guidelines to prompt engineering for teachers. Here is the result: **A teachers’ guide to prompt engineering with ChatGPT** ***PROMPT: I want to create a precise guide to prompt engineering specifically for teachers and administrators in the field of K-12 education. Please generate 10 prompt examples demonstrating the key principles for creating outstanding prompts. For each example generate three prompts of differing quality, rated from a 1 (low) to 10 (high) scale. Example prompt: ChatGPT, generate a [activity category: ex, lesson plan, article, quiz, etc] lesson plan for [Subject] [Grade] [topic] [duration] [class size]. Integrate [instructional model] and [framework].*** *Example 1: Creating a project-based lesson plan for 4th grade science on ecosystems* 1/10: Write a lesson plan for kids about ecosystems. 5/10: Create a 4th grade science lesson plan on ecosystems for a 1-hour class. 10/10: ChatGPT, generate a project-based lesson plan for 4th grade science focused on ecosystems for a 1-hour duration with 25 students. Integrate inquiry-based learning and the 5E instructional model. *Example 2: Designing an interactive quiz for 3rd grade math on fractions* 1/10: Make a math quiz on fractions for kids. 5/10: Create a quiz for 3rd graders on fractions that lasts 45 minutes. 10/10: ChatGPT, generate an interactive quiz for 3rd grade math focusing on fractions for a 45-minute duration with 20 students. Incorporate project-based learning and align with the Common Core Standards. *Example 3: Developing an informative article for 6th grade history on ancient civilizations* 1/10: Write a history article on old civilizations. 5/10: Design an informative article for 6th graders on ancient civilizations lasting 1.5 hours. 10/10: ChatGPT, generate an informative article for 6th grade history centered on ancient civilizations for a 1.5-hour duration with 30 students. Integrate differentiated instruction and apply the Understanding by Design framework. *Example 4: Crafting a collaborative activity for 7th grade language arts on persuasive writing* 1/10: Make an English activity on persuasive writing. 5/10: Develop a collaborative activity for 7th graders on persuasive writing for 1 hour. 10/10: ChatGPT, generate a collaborative activity for 7th grade language arts focused on persuasive writing for a 1-hour duration with 25 students. Incorporate cooperative learning and use the Workshop Model for instruction. *Example 5: Creating a simulation game for 5th grade physical education on teamwork and sportsmanship* 1/10: Write a PE game on teamwork for kids. 5/10: Design a 5th grade PE simulation game on teamwork and sportsmanship for 30 minutes. 10/10: ChatGPT, generate a simulation game for 5th grade physical education emphasizing teamwork and sportsmanship for a 30-minute duration with 15 students. Integrate game-based learning and apply the Teaching Personal and Social Responsibility (TPSR) model. *Example 6: Developing a hands-on activity for 2nd grade music on rhythm and melody* 1/10: Make a music activity about rhythm and melody. 5/10: Create a 2nd grade music hands-on activity on rhythm and melody for 40 minutes. 10/10: ChatGPT, generate a hands-on activity for 2nd grade music focused on rhythm and melody for a 40-minute duration with 20 students. Incorporate the Orff-Schulwerk approach and the Kodály method for instruction. *Example 7: Crafting a creative assignment for 8th grade art on color theory* 1/10: Write an art assignment on color stuff. 5/10: Design a creative assignment for 8th graders on color theory lasting 1 hour. 10/10: ChatGPT, generate a creative assignment for 8th grade art centered on color theory for a 1-hour duration with 18 students. column36:
The Complete List of Teaching Methods
Teaching Methods: Not as Simple as ABC

Whether you’re a longtime educator, preparing to start your first teaching job, or mapping out your dream of a career in the classroom, the topic of teaching methods is one that means many different things to different people.

Your individual approaches and strategies to imparting knowledge to your students and inspiring them to learn are probably built on your academic education as well as your instincts and intuition.

Whether you come by your preferred teaching methods organically or by actively studying educational theory and pedagogy, it can be helpful to have a comprehensive working knowledge of the various teaching methods at your disposal.

Get your FREE Teaching Methods Guide here:
https://onlinedegrees.sandiego.edu/complete-list-teaching-methods/

In this book, we will examine the historical development of Artificial Intelligence in education and the current state of AI technology in the classroom. We will explore the types of AI used in education, such as machine learning, natural language processing, intelligent tutoring systems, and more. We will also examine the advantages and disadvantages of using AI in education, as well as the potential risks of replacing teachers with AI. https://www.teacherspayteachers.com/Product/The-AI-Education-RevolutionWhat-Does-the-Future-Hold-for-Teachers-9412458 I. The Rise of AI in Education * Historical development of AI in education * Current state of AI in education * Types of AI used in education (e.g., machine learning, natural language processing, intelligent tutoring systems) * Advantages and disadvantages of using AI in education * The potential impact of AI on the education industry II. The Role of Teachers in Education * The traditional role of teachers in the classroom * The changing role of teachers in the AI era * How AI can supplement and enhance the role of teachers * Potential risks of replacing teachers with AI III. AI and Student Learning * Personalized learning with AI * Adaptive learning and assessment * Augmented and virtual reality in education * Social and emotional learning with AI IV. Ethical and Practical Considerations * Privacy and data security * Bias in AI algorithms * The digital divide and access to technology * Equity and inclusivity in AI education V. The Future of AI in Education * Emerging AI technologies and their potential impact on education * The evolving role of teachers in the AI era * The potential for AI to transform education systems globally * The importance of collaboration between AI and human teachers

Educators have an obligation to collaborate with their students on integrating AI effectively in instruction and learning. The most important reason to do this is not educational integrity (although that is also important) It IS about educational EQUITY. AI is a certainty in that will pervade all of their future careers. Not including it will endorse inequities and hurt students. While it may pain us to go through this educational evolution so quickly, not doing it is actually harmful. As the tech coach for my district, I used to think resorting to pen and paper was an okay stopgap, but I changed my mind and will no longer tell teachers it is okay. Technology has afforded our students with assistive technologies and all of us the power to collaborate and provide faster feedback. It changed formative assessment for the better. Taking away those tools is also an equity issue. As someone who will be guiding teachers and leaders in a huge district, this is what I plan to lead with moving forward.

Hi! High school math teacher here. Looking for ways that folks have used AI to help them support students/ make their lives easier in ways other than creating assessments. Here’s some of they ways I’ve used it for so far and have been super impressed: 1. Gave it all my standards and had it write I can statements. This was incredible and am planning on using that statements next year as I transition to standards based grading. 2. Create formulas to help students explore monthly payment plans of loans with various compounding interests. I had to edit the equations because they were not correct, but they were a great starting point that cut down on my time creating the activity. 3. Coaching students on using AI to generate ideas for projects and define research questions. Have seen this cut down significantly on the “per-research” phase of a project where students are determining their specific topics.
