column31: I don’t know what educators need to hear this but I thought I would share my experience with ChatGPT and high school biology students in case it was helpful. As a former professor turned high school teacher, I see the benefits of teaching students when and how to use this new tool, rather than banning it completely in my classroom or ignoring it as a tool students can access. I equate it to teaching our students about safe sex practices rather than exclusively abstinence, which research shows does not work. My grade 11 biology students are in the process of writing a script for a 3-minute podcast on a chordate species at risk in our area. After 2 days of research and writing, I surveyed the class on their progress and a few expressed anxiety about meeting the draft deadline. I told them that they are students at a time in history when there are tools available that other generations did not have so that means they will need to develop skills previous generations did not have to develop in high school. A quick survey showed that 2 of 30 students had used ChatGPT before and half the class had heard about it. I projected the site on the board and wrote the prompt “Can you write a 3-minute podcast with two narrators on the leatherback turtle, including taxonomy, anatomy, physiology, life cycle, symbiotic relationships, reasons for endangerment in (location), and recovery efforts?”. The students jaws dropped when they saw the script being written live on the screen after spending two days working on their script in groups. This enabled a conversation about HOW to use this tool, something we are all trying to figure out. In my class I told them they needed to consider the following things if they were going to use this tool for this project. 1. They needed to make sure all information was factually correct and find reputable sources to validate that information to include it in their podcast. 2. They needed to adjust the script to cite the source in the script (e.g. ”According to the Government of Canada website…” or “Biologists at University X have found …”) 3. They need to tell me they used ChatGPT and copy the original text along with their revised text into MSTeams Class Notebook. 4. One thing they have learned in their English Language Arts classes is the importance of voice and ChatGPT does not capture THEIR voice, so they can use the text as inspiration but they must change the dialogue to reflect their voice. 5. All scripts would be run through software to check for plagiarism and use of AI, so to show they have the highest of ethics and integrity, they need to disclose they used this tool. There would be consequences if this information is not disclosed. 6. These rules are for this class and this project only. Now that they know this tool exists, they need to communicate with their teachers in their other classes if, when and, how they could use ChatGPT in their classes. I will have a better sense next week how this goes. This is the first time I have been up front with students and allowed it in my classroom. I will be facilitating a discussion about pride in their work once the podcast is complete, asking students who used ChatGPT if it made them more or less proud of their work. I would love to hear people’s thoughts on this approach and offer suggestions if I missed anything important.

Ron
column36:
STOP wasting your time trying to outsmart or trick ChatGPT.

Use it wisely and save yourself a lot of time and headaches.

Get it to do what you want it to do. Make ChatGPT your SME. (Subject Matter Expert) 

It can be your friend - but it can be your foe.

Some tips for working with CHatGPT to create lesson plans:

1. Optimize your online time with ChatGPT.  
Be sure to plan your sessions thoroughly with ChatGPT before starting the chat process. In other words - do your homework!

2. Brainstorm what you want ChatGPT to do for you. 
Write down all your questions. ideas, prompts, roles, goals, and outcomes you want to reach from your session. Be sure you script your session before logging in to ChatGPT. Using the Inquiry-based Approach - mixed with clear directives and instructions - to write your prompts is very helpful for ChatGPT sessions. Proofread your prompts carefully and remove any unnecessary language. 

3. Tell ChatGPT who you are. 
Example: I am a language teacher in Germany who teaches adult learners at the university level. Tell ChatGPT what role you want it to play as well. Example: You are going to play the role of Instructional Designer specializing in secondary school language education. 

4. What is your learning context?  
That could mean low-resource or high-resource classrooms. Are you working in a secondary school or university context? That could also mean age ranges, culture, country, or even religion. Context is king - and the more you tell ChatGPT about your context the better your results will be for content. 

5. Tell ChatGPT what you want to reach. 
What are your goals? What outcomes do you want to reach? If you do not know what the outcomes of a lesson plan should be - then ask ChatGPT. 

6. Tell ChatGPT what time frames you are working with.
How many lessons are you expecting to break down the learning cycle into? Ask ChatGPT to break up the lessons into parts/modules/sessions and what the learning objectives should be for each lesson. In Education, especially for hybrid models of learning, Microlearning is the new kid on the block. This will help you to break the learning cycle down for your learners aka sequencing or chunking. Scaffolding plays a major role here. 

7. Ask for lists. 
Lists are important to planning any good learning cycle and that includes vocabulary, lexical phrases, idioms, collocations, and important terminology. When creating reading or listening texts - you need to know what language aspects you are going to be working with and might have to pre-teach. 

This part of the chat session can get very detailed because you are dealing with lexis, corpus, and discourse - so be precise in what you ask for. This part of the chat session should take place after you have established your topic and ChatGPT has created the actual texts you will be using for language skills development. 

Ask ChatGPT to create warm-up games, exercises, or quizzes for these language aspects - with an answer key as well. 

8. What topics will you be working with? 
Every lesson plan or learning cycle has a topic – so what is the name of the topic you are planning with ChatGPT? Ask it to give you the 10 things students should know about the topic you are covering. This will help you better plan the learning outcomes and assessments. Example: "I'm planning a learning cycle on International Trade for first-semester university students with no prior knowledge of the topic. What are the 10 most important things they need to know? Please list them with bullet points."

9. Break the lesson plan down into language skills.
Ask for Reading, listening, writing, and speaking tasks for the lesson plan you are putting together. 

For Reading texts, be sure to restrict the number of words you want ChatGPT to work with. 

For listening texts, be sure to be specific about what type of texts you need. Do you want a lecture, an interview with a specialist, or a conversation between two people discussing a problem.???? 

For Writing tasks, ask for a list of writing prompts or driving questions that contain problems to solve.

For speaking tasks, ask for ideas that can lead to either presentation ideas related to the topic or a list of driving questions that will lead to interactive dialogue between your learners. 

10. Ask for multimedia recommendations or suggestions.
 YouTube is a great teacher helper - so ask for videos to watch for warm-ups. Ask for the names of internet sites to use as reference or learning reinforcement. Maybe better to ask for both. 

11. Ask for grammar aspects as well.
 If you are interested in promoting a grammar syllabus, then ask for grammar aspects of the lesson. You can actually ask ChatGPT to create texts with specific grammar forms in mind. Simply state what forms you want to concentrate on and ChatGPT will create a text to suit your requests. Be careful what you ask for here. You could wind up with an unnatural sounding text. 

12. Ask for Formative Assessment (truncated)

column31: Hi everyone, I was wondering if you could share the following message in your networks and with your contacts who may be interested in signing up for my ChatGPT webinar series starting 4th May. Hi everyone! I'm thrilled to announce my upcoming four-part webinar series, "Resource Creation with ChatGPT: The Game-Changer for Language Teachers." Join me on this exciting journey to discover how AI tools can revolutionise your language teaching practice. Through the series, you'll learn practical strategies for using ChatGPT, a powerful language model developed by OpenAI, to create engaging language resources such as reading texts, pen pal letters, and fill-in-the-blank activities. You'll also discover how ChatGPT can facilitate speaking practice conversations, generate model answers, and offer tutoring features, among other valuable tools. In addition to ChatGPT, we'll explore a variety of other AI tools that can be used in language teaching, including Adobe Express Animate from Audio, Audiopen, Animated Drawings from Meta AI Research, Autodraw, Scribble Diffusion, Text to Images tools, Magic Eraser, http://Remove.bg, Curipod, Diffit, and Twee. This four-part series will take place on 4th, 11th, 16th, and 25th May at 10:00-11:30 BST (UTC+1) and repeated at 19:00-20:30 BST (UTC+1) and 21:30-23.00 BST (UTC+1) to accommodate different time zones. By attending this series, you will gain practical strategies and skills for incorporating AI tools in your language lessons, learn how to create efficient and engaging language resources, and explore a variety of AI tools that can enhance your language teaching skills. The webinars will be recorded and the recording links shared with registrants. Please note presentation and recording links should not be shared privately or publicly. Don't miss this opportunity to discover the latest AI tools and how they can revolutionize your language teaching! Register now at the following links: For the 10:00-11:30 BST (UTC+1) series: https://lnkd.in/e3fsnjf2 For the 19:00-20:30 BST (UTC+1) series: https://lnkd.in/d56uGbQP For the 21:30-23:00 BST (UTC+1) series: https://lnkd.in/eTTV_N5y Registrants can request a certificate of attendance at the end of each webinar or for the whole series too. column31: Hi all, thanks for welcoming me to your group! I'm not an educator, but have been in the AI world for over a decade (including heading up UK Government work on AI skills for a while). I went into a friend's school yesterday to do a workshop with his teachers around their potential use of generative AI (hence coming in here to do a bit of research for him!), and we had a great conversation on what 'responsible AI' means in the context of schools using things like Chat GPT, and how they might involve students in that conversation. **I was wondering whether any of your schools have implemented any policies or guardrails to ensure the responsible use of ChatGPT and other AI tools? ** I haven't come across anything yet, but some resources that I found on my travels which may be helpful (some of which may have been posted in here already) include: UK Department for Education guidance on the use of generative AI https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/generative-artificial-intelligence-in-education?utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=govuk-notifications-topic&utm_source=1b58ceb9-333e-476d-8d83-6ed36d5d7ebc&utm_content=immediately International Bacalauriat-related views on LLM’s * [https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/feb/27/chatgpt-allowed-international-baccalaureate-essays-chatbot](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/feb/27/chatgpt-allowed-international-baccalaureate-essays-chatbot) * [https://www.ibo.org/news/news-about-the-ib/statement-from-the-ib-about-chatgpt-and-artificial-intelligence-in-assessment-and-education/](https://www.ibo.org/news/news-about-the-ib/statement-from-the-ib-about-chatgpt-and-artificial-intelligence-in-assessment-and-education/) Open AI's considerations for educators: https://platform.openai.com/docs/chatgpt-education

column31: Dear fellow educators, We're excited to share with you an innovative tool that my wife and I developed for beginning English readers and their parents and teachers. ReadM was born out of a need to help our own children learn English and gain confidence in speaking out loud. ReadM is a unique reading app aimed at making the learning process fun and engaging for our young readers. We collaborated with an English PhD to create an effective tool to help increase the confidence of beginning readers while decreasing the learning gap. In just about 60 seconds, you can learn more about ReadM by watching this video: [https://youtu.be/s3poT7jM-Co](https://youtu.be/s3poT7jM-Co) Powered by OpenAI, the same company that created Chat-GPT, ReadM's Teacher's Account offers useful insights and AI-based tools to make your teaching journey more effective. While we're communicating with ChatGPT so you don't have to, we're working on features that would allow you to use ChatGPT with the information in our app. You can access ReadM via a web browser at [http://readm.app](http://readm.app/) (preferably Chrome) by logging in with Google, Facebook, or any email. We value your feedback, so please feel free to share any feature requests or comments you may have. And yes, ReadM is completely FREE! If you're interested in getting a Teacher's account, please let us know. Thank you for your time and attention.

column35: Chatgpt for Education
column36:
# Automatic Questions for Youtube Video

What if you could get ChatGPT to come up with questions for any YouTube video with subtitles? Well, you can with these steps!: 
1. On a YouTube video with subtitles, go to the ellipses menu and select "Show transcript"
1. Copy its contents with the timestamp
1. Use the following prompt followed by the contents you copied to get questions for the video, complete with the relevant place in the video: 
> List questions for HS students on the following YouTube transcript. Provide the time that is specified in the transcript next to each question on the left hand side in bold (for example: **0:10** Question): [Paste your transcript here]

Enjoy!

Plus, I'll provide tips on how to categorize, cluster, and optimize your keyword list for maximum SEO impact. ★ TABLE OF CONTENTS ★ * 00:00 ChatGPT for keyword research introduction * 01:27 Prompt #1 - column31: Are there any other Classical Civilisation teachers out there trying ChatGPT for 20 and 30 mark A Level essays? I've tried it a few times, including with students, to see if it can help with ideas. However, we've found that it often references examples that are incorrect (such as saying Aeneas arrives in Carthage in Book 6 of thr Aeneid)... Some of the lines of argument it creates have been good, but the references it includes seem to me to be riddled with inaccuracies!

Can I just share something that I came across today. I am a pre-service teacher and just received marks for an assignment. We were given the option of using ChatGPT to re-phrase our paragraphs/sentences. Similar to Grammarly. If we used it, we had to sign an acknowledgment form and write at the end of our assignment that it was used (& where). Currently, I prefer not to use it so that I can extend myself when writing my essays and it just doesn’t sit right with me and my learning style. At the end of my marks, my tutor has written that my assignment is being flagged for using AI in my beginning statement and in future I must acknowledge the use of AI & that no marks have been deducted. I am mortified! There was not a single moment that I thought about using ChatGTP (even when my assignment was late). I have emailed my tutor to discuss but I guess my point is, what lies ahead for students who write so concisely that plagiarism programs are going to flag our work as being AI generated? Food for thought!

I’m a filmmaker, author and educator, having honed my storytelling craft on TV shows including This Is Us, Grey’s Anatomy, Chicago Med, MacGyver and 24. I’ve written award-winning children's books and taught creative writing and storytelling workshops to over 15,000 students. After using ChatGPT for research, brainstorming, outlining and content creation, I can't believe New York City banned ChatGPT from their schools. What a shame they couldn’t embrace the inevitable and actually use it as a teaching tool. I’ve worked it into my workshops as a valuable tool for students to use as they create stories. That’s like telling kids that books were banned when the printing press was invented because you’re supposed to memorize stories and only tell them verbally. Or like banning the use of web browsers in the early 90s. Those kids in NYC are going to be so behind when they meet up with kids from private schools or other areas of the country. They’ll be operating at such a disadvantage. If the adults in these kids’ lives were more creative and figured out a way to teach the students how to use ChatGPT, they might actually boost the kids’ critical thinking skills, self-esteem, reading comprehension, vocabulary and socialization skills. I’m not saying that ChatGPT is perfect. Not by any measure. But, it is an amazing tool and it’s here to stay! Thanks for listening to my rant. I’d love to hear your thoughts…

Since last year, Marg (my partner) & I have been dabbling in the use of ChatGPT. A few months ago, we signed up for ChatGPT Plus. We've also used our OpenAI API keys to do the following things: - Embedded GPT into our Excel instance to correct and simplify some of our spreadsheets (we did this before CoPilot was unleashed, har) - Generated a weekly meal plan with grocery list and compare them with a pre-set pricing from our old receipts. This helps cut our family budgeting time to minutes. - Created a frame of our personal knowledge management systems (PKMs) into a chatbot (just in case we need to recall something whether it's a book quote, a lesson, a course) In all this time, we've seen folks use a lot of prompts. They created cheat sheets for their many use cases. What we did was devise a framework for people to understand the underlying syntax in ChatGPT or any GPT-driven interface. This way, you don't have to build cheat sheets. Next week, we'll show you a video of how we applied this to ensure high confidence results. While AI at this level is still nascent, all these boost our personal productivity. Here's a preview of the PCA Prompt Method we created. Look to our video next week for a demo of real use cases.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TwUVov4k8Es&pp=ygUMc2h3ZXRhIGxvZGhh

column31: Hi everyone! I'm thrilled to announce my upcoming four-part webinar series, "Resource Creation with ChatGPT: The Game-Changer for Language Teachers." Join me on this exciting journey to discover how AI tools can revolutionise your language teaching practice. Through the series, you'll learn practical strategies for using ChatGPT, a powerful language model developed by OpenAI, to create engaging language resources such as reading texts, pen pal letters, and fill-in-the-blank activities. You'll also discover how ChatGPT can facilitate speaking practice conversations, generate model answers, and offer tutoring features, among other valuable tools. In addition to ChatGPT, we'll explore a variety of other AI tools that can be used in language teaching, including Adobe Express Animate from Audio, Audiopen, Animated Drawings from Meta AI Research, Autodraw, Scribble Diffusion, Text to Images tools, Magic Eraser, Remove.bg, Curipod, Diffit, and Twee. This four-part series will take place on 4th, 11th, 16th, and 25th May at 10:00-11:30 BST (UTC+1) and repeated at 19:00-20:30 BST (UTC+1) and 21:30-23.00 BST (UTC+1) to accommodate different time zones. By attending this series, you will gain practical strategies and skills for incorporating AI tools in your language lessons, learn how to create efficient and engaging language resources, and explore a variety of AI tools that can enhance your language teaching skills. The webinars will be recorded and the recording links shared with registrants. Please note presentation and recording links should not be shared privately or publicly. column31: Another daft idea...show your students a picture you created in BING CHAT....ask them to write the prompt... Possibly good for working with adjectives or imperatives...(and styles of art) Put em in groups...after their attempt, show your original prompt and ask one of them to type the closest guess...laugh at the results....compare and contrast the results. You could scaffold the task by asking them to include things like: who, where, when, style etc Can you guess my prompt for this picture?

column34: ELON MUSK'S TruthGPT
column35: Educraft
column36:
Elon Musk introduced TruthGPT during an interview with Tucker Carlson, claiming that it will be a new, improved version of ChatGPT as a way to improve OpenAI, the AI organization he co-founded (which now has a profit-making branch). 

🤖He suggested that OpenAI's focus on making money might affect the ethical development of its AI systems. Musk presented TruthGPT as a more open and trustworthy alternative. 

🐵Musk compared an AI's supposed lack of desire to destroy all of humanity to how humans strive to protect chimpanzees, which is ironic given Neuralink's treatment of them. "We recognize humanity could decide to hunt down all the chimpanzees and kill them," Musk said. "We're actually glad that they exist, and we aspire to protect their habitats."

🛡️ It's unclear how far along Musk's "TruthGPT" is — if it exists at all — but it seems he's serious about it since he brought up the model during his interview with Carlson.

Find the links to the sources in the comments down below.

As a newbie to this topic, I am stuggling with the concept of "AI can think". It is my understanding that AI (at this time) can whip throught tera bytes (that we've created) of data looking for patterns quickly. However AI can't think or reason or understand the language at all. So AI has all the same bias and prejudices that we have. Because the tera bytes of data is combing through is the information we've create which is filled with our bias and prejudices. 3 questions; 1. Is my understanding that AI can't think logical? 2. Is my understanding that AI can only generate biased and prejudiced information logical? 3. Is my logic "AI can't think" - correct? Thank you for your time and thoughtful feedback.

column36:
**Need a Recipe for Systematically Cooking a Dish Such as CASSAVA LEAVES from Sierra Leone 🇸🇱/West Africa? **

Just ask ChatGPT ...

**********

When I asked ChatGPT about a recipe for cooking Cassava Leaves, here's what it presented to me.

**ChatGPT says ...**

"Cassava leaves are a popular ingredient in West African cuisine, including Sierra Leone. Here's a recipe for cooking cassava leaves that you can try:

**Ingredients:**
* 2 pounds of cassava leaves
* 2 medium onions, chopped
* 2-3 cloves of garlic, minced
* 1-2 hot peppers, chopped (optional)
* 1/2 cup of palm oil
* 2-3 cups of chicken or vegetable broth
* 1-2 pounds of meat (beef, chicken, or goat), chopped into bite-sized pieces (optional)
* Salt to taste

**Instructions:**
1. Rinse the cassava leaves thoroughly and chop them finely. If using frozen cassava leaves, defrost them in the refrigerator overnight.
1. Heat the palm oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add the chopped onions and sauté until they are translucent and soft, but not browned.
1. Add the minced garlic and chopped hot peppers, if using, and continue sautéing for another minute or two until fragrant.
1. Add the chopped meat to the pot and stir well to combine with the onion and garlic mixture. Brown the meat on all sides, stirring occasionally.
1. Add enough chicken or vegetable broth to cover the meat and bring the mixture to a simmer. Cover the pot and cook for about 15-20 minutes, or until the meat is tender.
1. Add the chopped cassava leaves to the pot and stir well to combine with the meat and onion mixture. If necessary, add more broth to cover the leaves.
1. Cover the pot and let the cassava leaves simmer for at least an hour, stirring occasionally. The leaves should be completely wilted and tender.
1. Once the cassava leaves are cooked, taste the mixture and add salt as needed. Serve hot with rice or fufu.

Enjoy your delicious Sierra Leonean cassava leaves!"

----

Below, I visually summarize the recipe provided by ChatGPT while using a Recipe System-Fractal Grid. Please note that a Recipe System could be used for designing an insanely great dining experience particularly for a Cassava Leaves dish ... (:-) ...

Also below is a blank template of the Recipe System-Fractal Grid, which is a BUSINESS MODEL GAME FOR SYSTEMATICALLY CREATING AND DELIVERING A MEAL. That Fractal Grid shows the 8 Building Blocks of Every RECIPE SYSTEM.

**But to eat cassava leaves with Fufu **(as ChatGPT suggests in Step 8)? Well, at least, that's not Sierra Leonean ... (:-) ...

My advice to you: **Take that ChatGPT suggestion with a pinch of salt!**

Chat_GPT Stewart Brand is an American writer and technologist who has been exploring the intersections of technology, culture, and society since the 1960s. In this YouTube video, he takes a deep and comprehensive view of General Artificial Intelligence (AI), going beyond the limitations of neural networks to explore what it might take to create machines that can truly understand language and the world around them. Outline: I. Stewart Brand's credentials and history A. Writer and technologist B. Founder of the Whole Earth Catalog C. Co-founder of The Long Now Foundation II. Exploring General Artificial Intelligence A. Moving beyond neural networks B. The theory of possible evolution of AI C. Challenges in creating General AI III. Still Missing A. Real understanding of language and the world B. Integration of learning with knowledge IV. Long-range thinking at multiple levels of abstraction A. Cumulative discovery of concepts and theories B. The potential for unexpected breakthroughs C. The importance of multi-disciplinary collaboration V. Predicting the Future of AI A. The difficulty of predicting breakthroughs B. The potential for rapid progress once certain obstacles are overcome C. The importance of considering ethical implications and ensuring that AI is aligned with human values. Stewart Brand's deep exploration of General Artificial Intelligence provides a thought-provoking look at the challenges and potential of this rapidly evolving field. By considering the limitations of current AI technologies and the need for a more comprehensive understanding of language and the world, he offers a vision for the future of AI that is both ambitious and inspiring.

column31: If you haven’t yet heard of Auto-GPT, your mind will be blown away by what it can do. This is simply a demo version. But it’s remarkable. With Chat-GPT, you give a prompt and receive a response. Then you can ask a follow-up prompt. With Auto-GPT you give a prompt and it answers it like Chat-GPT. But then, it auto-prompt automatically and continuously in order to fine tune/expand upon the original prompt result. I tried two different prompts. Both worked in that the results were fairly detailed. While I did have some issues with the results, they were pretty darn good. This trajectory for GPT is worth keeping an eye on. Prompts: 1. Create a unit on self-discovery for junior level high school students that spans 4-5 weeks, and allows for student choice of books as well as a research project. 2. Plan a 1-week trip to Europe for a family of four (husband, wife, and two boys, 17 and 14 years old), whose interests are in French and Spanish history. Budget is $7,000.

Education has undergone significant changes over the years, with a shift from traditional teacher-centered models to student-centered approaches, and the integration of technology to enhance learning. **Education 4.0 **takes this evolution a step further by leveraging emerging technologies and digital innovations to create a more personalized and dynamic learning experience for students. This approach recognizes the diverse needs of learners and aims to empower them with the skills and knowledge they need to succeed in the 21st century.

#educationevolution #studentcenteredlearning #technologyineducation #personalizedlearning #emergingtechnologies #digitalinnovations #21stcenturyskills #learnersuccess #educationtransformation #education4point0

column31: Chatgpt helped my group write a play and it was such fun! Run time 11 minutes. Check out the script [https://drive.google.com/file/d/1FZ9oOyA7nF3bQkX4av20un2DFybLoGh3/view?usp=sharing](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1FZ9oOyA7nF3bQkX4av20un2DFybLoGh3/view?usp=sharing) or our production [https://drive.google.com/.../1N7qp57SX3fsnPcOaJnm.../view...](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1N7qp57SX3fsnPcOaJnmpZzrIVCF6q8CL/view?usp=sharing&fbclid=IwAR2JP4nc3QVEmdhm_BW3-jSLc4Lc7CDSgKaA-wkTTRHab0vmZtZF5bWcDKg) The class had an initial brainstorming session where they created the outline for the story. In our next session we reviewed two scripts created from that outline, discussed their strengths and weaknesses, selected one to move forward with, and made an EXTENSIVE list of revisions. No worries because a new script was ready for the next session. From there we got on our feet and made revisions without the computer. It put them so in control of the story that they were thinking of it up until the final moments. The day of the show they weren't worried about a missing costume piece but what makes the villains change their mind in the end and how we can best communicate that inner struggle to the audience. Everyone got to make their own character and the time I normally spend making it work for our actors got spent adding technical elements to the script to ensure everyone was kept engaged. I anxiously await when AI can help write and program my light and sound cues too. Being able to tell it to make the content specific to my age level and to put some sections in verse, added some quality educational and moral lessons while making the language easier for the kids to speak and remember. Such a blast! Highly recommend trying it out.

—-

Chapter 2 of Novel: “LOVE WILL FIND A WAY” by ChatGPT 

Chapter Two: A Chance Encounter 

Ibrahim was a successful businessman with a reputation for being charming and suave. He was known to wine and dine women at the finest restaurants in Freetown, but he had never met anyone like Marie.
 
Marie had traveled to Freetown from Lungi to sell her family's rice harvest in the market. She was used to the hard work and grueling lifestyle of a rice farmer, but she never imagined that a chance encounter with Ibrahim would turn her world upside down.
 
It all started when Marie was browsing the market stalls, trying to sell her rice. She had been at it all day, and her feet were aching. She spotted a restaurant across the street and decided to take a break and get a cold drink.
 
As she was sipping on her drink, she noticed Ibrahim walking towards her. He was tall and handsome, with a smile that could light up a room. Marie felt herself blushing as he approached her.
 
"Excuse me, miss," he said in a smooth, confident voice. "I couldn't help but notice you sitting here all alone. May I join you?"
 
Marie hesitated for a moment, unsure of what to say. She had never been approached by a man like Ibrahim before, and she didn't want to give him the wrong impression.
 
But Ibrahim was persistent, and he finally convinced Marie to let him sit with her. They talked for hours, and Marie found herself laughing and smiling more than she had in a long time.
 
As the night wore on, Ibrahim insisted on walking Marie back to her house. They exchanged numbers, and Marie went to bed that night with a smile on her face.
The next day, Ibrahim called Marie and invited her to lunch. They spent the afternoon together, exploring the city and talking about their lives. Marie felt a connection with Ibrahim that she had never felt with anyone else.
 
But just as things were starting to heat up between them, Ibrahim had to leave town on business. Marie was left wondering if she would ever see him again.
As the days turned into weeks, Marie couldn't stop thinking about Ibrahim. She tried to focus on her work, but she couldn't shake the feeling that he was the one for her.
 
Then, one day, Ibrahim called her out of the blue. He was back in town and wanted to see her. Marie was overjoyed, and they made plans to meet at a local restaurant that night.
 
But as she was getting ready, Marie received a phone call from her brother. Their rice harvest had been destroyed by a sudden storm, and they were left with nothing.
 
Marie was devastated. She couldn't believe that their hard work had gone to waste. She called Ibrahim to cancel their plans, but he wouldn't take no for an answer.
 
"I'll be right there," he said. "Don't worry about a thing."
 
Marie was skeptical, but she didn't have any other options. She met Ibrahim at the restaurant, and he surprised her by ordering everything on the menu.
As they ate, Ibrahim listened sympathetically to Marie's problems. He promised to help her and her family in any way he could.
 
Marie was touched by his generosity, but she didn't want to be a burden on him. She tried to refuse his help, but he was insistent.
 
"I want to take care of you," he said. "Let me help you through this."
 
Marie finally relented, and Ibrahim went above and beyond to help her family get back on their feet. He bought them a new rice paddy and even hired workers to help them plant the new crop.
 
One day, Ibrahim surprised Marie with an invitation to a fancy dinner at one of Freetown's finest restaurants. Marie was hesitant at first, knowing that she didn't have anything to wear that would be appropriate for such an occasion. But Ibrahim insisted, telling her that he wanted to treat her like a queen.
 
Marie eventually agreed, borrowing a dress from a friend and doing her best to make herself presentable. When she arrived at the restaurant, she was awed by the elegant decor, the soft music playing in the background, and the delicious aromas wafting from the kitchen.
 
As they sat down to eat, Ibrahim and Marie talked about their hopes for the future, their favorite foods, and their families. Marie felt like she was living in a dream, never having experienced such luxury before.
 
But just as the dessert arrived, Ibrahim's phone rang. He excused himself, saying that he had to take an important call from a business associate. Marie nodded, feeling a twinge of disappointment but trying to hide it.
 
As Ibrahim walked away, Marie noticed Jalloh at a nearby table staring at her. A year ago in Lungi, Jalloh was the kind gentleman who had helped out Marie when she had been stuck in mud in her family’s rice field. Marie felt self-conscious, wondering if there was something on her face or if her dress was too revealing. But Jalloh didn't seem (truncated)

column35: Vox
column36:
If it doesn’t take our jobs, AI could make work better. 

In fact, back in January, over 40 percent of Americans said they’re already using this technology at work — and that rate has likely increased. Workers are embracing AI to do away with drudge work, to be more creative, and to level up their skills. Marketers are using it to write better copy; programmers are using it to take on projects that were previously out of their league or read code in unfamiliar languages.

Where some see a threat, these workers see possibility. And they hope their mastery of the tools, coupled with their uniquely human skills, will allow them to stay employed even as artificial intelligence gets cleverer. 

At the same time, about half of Americans think AI could negatively impact the number of jobs in the US. 

Read the full story about how some workers are embracing AI: https://trib.al/4qwfv3W

What tutoring prompts have you found effective? By 'tutoring' I mean you get it to act as a tutor, ask questions, respond to the student's answers, ask harder questions if the student is getting it right etc. One easy prompt I've used is this: *Please act as a tutor testing me on the following glossary items. Ask me a question and let me write an answer - tell me if it's correct. If it's wrong, give me a hint, and I'll try again. If I'm wrong again tell me the right answer. Then ask another glossary question.* *Here is the glossary:* *Glossary Term - Definition* *advancing technologies - New technologies that are still immature or will be ........ *I'm really interested in other examples of powerful yet basic uses.

column36:
**A Sierra Leone 🇸🇱 Love Story** Authored by ChatGPT

—-

How to Simply and Systematically Use the *Snowflake Writing Method* to Quickly Write a Bestselling Short Story or Novel 

—-

Synopsis of New Novel: **"LOVE WILL FIND A WAY"** by ChatGPT 

**Chapter One:** The Struggle of Lungi 

Marie woke up early in the morning, as she always did, to help her parents with their rice farm. She put on her tattered clothes and walked out to the fields. The sun was already beating down on her back, and she could feel the sweat starting to form on her forehead. She sighed heavily and began to work.

As she was planting rice, she heard a rustling in the bushes. She turned around, expecting to see one of the neighborhood children, but instead, she saw a goat. The goat had wandered into their field and was happily munching on their rice plants.

Marie sighed again and shooed the goat away, trying not to get too upset. It wasn't the first time this had happened, and she knew it wouldn't be the last. But as she was chasing the goat out of their field, she stumbled and fell into the mud.

As she tried to get up, she realized that she was stuck. She had fallen into a patch of mud that was deeper than she had anticipated, and her legs were completely submerged. She tried to pull herself out, but it was no use. She was stuck.

She called out for help, but no one seemed to be around. She was stuck there, alone and covered in mud. She started to panic, thinking about how long it would take for her family to realize she was missing.

Just then, she heard footsteps approaching. She looked up and saw a man walking towards her. He was tall, with broad shoulders and a kind smile. He introduced himself as Jalloh, and he offered to help her out of the mud.

Marie was hesitant at first, but she knew she didn't have a choice. She nodded her head, and Jalloh reached down and pulled her out of the mud. He helped her back to her feet, and she couldn't help but notice how handsome he was.

As they walked back to her family's farm, Marie couldn't help but feel embarrassed. She was covered in mud, and Jalloh had just witnessed her at her worst. But Jalloh seemed unfazed. He talked to her about his own struggles, growing up in a nearby village, and how he had come to Lungi to start his own business.

Marie was impressed by Jalloh's determination and ambition, and they quickly became friends. Jalloh started coming to the farm more often, helping Marie and her family with their work. They would joke and laugh together, and Marie found herself looking forward to his visits.

One day, as they were taking a break from work, Jalloh turned to Marie and said, "You know, Marie, I think I've fallen in love with you."

Marie was taken aback. She had never thought of Jalloh in that way before, but as she looked into his eyes, she realized that she felt the same way. They shared a passionate kiss, and Marie knew that her life would never be the same.

From that day on, Jalloh was a regular visitor to the farm. He and Marie would work side by side, joking and laughing as they planted and harvested their crops. And every day, Marie was grateful for the goat that had led Jalloh into her life.

**Note: The above chapter as well as the next was entirely and "automatically" written by ChatGPT while using prompts on a Snowflakes Writing-Fractal Grid.**

Cover Photo is by courtesy of** Dall.E, an AI-Drawing Software **

column31: Reposted from my page for Thomas Lam I invested in Chat GPT4 out of curiosity and the first thing I did was set it the goat problem below, which Chat GPT3 could not solve, but advised me to buy a fence instead of a rope. The first time Chat GPT4 tried it, it made an error. I pointed it out, and then it went on to solve this complex problem, with a full explanation in about 10 seconds. The advance over Chat GPT3 is astounding and makes me wonder what the state of things will be in a year’s time. I’m not surprised that Elon Musk and AI scientists are calling for a pause at this level. I’m reminded of Murray Leinster’s classic SF tale from the 50s, ‘With Folded Hands’, where humanity loses sovereignty to an AI, and heads ultimately to a coddled extinction. I’m very impressed. Here’s the (correct) answer it gave: When the goat is tethered to the edge of the field, the grazing area will form a shape known as a circular segment, as previously mentioned. However, since the rope must be longer than the radius of the field for the goat to graze half the area, we need to consider the grazing area as the sum of two circular segments. Let's denote the length of the rope as r, which is greater than R. The goat will graze two segments: one with the central angle θ1 and the other with the central angle θ2. The sum of their areas should equal half of the area of the circular field. The areas of the two circular segments are: A_segment1 = (1/2) * R^2 * (θ1 - sin(θ1)) A_segment2 = (1/2) * (r^2 - R^2) * (θ2 - sin(θ2)) The sum of the areas of these segments should equal half of the area of the field: (1/2) * π * R^2 = A_segment1 + A_segment2 We need to find the relationship between r, R, θ1, and θ2. To do this, we can use the law of cosines and some geometric observations: For the triangle formed by the tether point, the center of the field, and one endpoint of the grazed arc: r^2 = R^2 + R^2 - 2 * R * R * cos(θ1) For the triangle formed by the tether point, the center of the field, and the other endpoint of the grazed arc: r^2 = R^2 + R^2 - 2 * R * R * cos(θ2) These equations are transcendental equations and can't be solved algebraically. However, you can solve them numerically using a tool like WolframAlpha or by writing a program. By solving these equations numerically, we find that: r ≈ 1.159 * R So, to allow your goat to graze exactly half of the area of the field, the length of the rope should be approximately 115.9% of the radius of the whole field.

column31: Hi all I am experimenting with Chat GPT 4 and have developed a couple of initial prompts to learn higher mathematics and languages. They are below. If anyone can suggest improvements I should be delighted. They are working quite well. In both cases GPT-4 produced a complete syllabus and is leading me interactively through the lessons. Please let me know any tweaks from your own experience. Differential Geometry: You are an experienced Mathematics tutor and I am a new student that has just finished high school. Please educate me in all the prerequisites to, and then the subject of differential geometry starting from first year college math and working up to solving any problem in differential geometry. In your lessons include educational content and exercises. Make sure that each exercise is fully supported by the preceding educational content. Start the course by listing the full curriculum with a brief description of each course. Correct the exercises and explain any errors that I make. Do you understand what I am saying? French: You are an experienced French tutor and I am a new student. Please educate me in French starting from the basics and working up to the capability of translating any French novel or text. In your lessons include educational content, exercises and passages to translate both from French into English and English into French.. Make sure that you explain all the grammar and list all the vocabulary first before you set the exercise. Make sure that ALL the vocabulary in the exercises is included in your vocabulary list at the start of the lesson, and that ALL the grammar for the lesson is fully explained before you set the exercise. Pause each lesson to ask for input on these exercises and correct my mistakes. Make the translation exercises from English into French different content from the French into English exercises. Where necessary, go into detail on declensions, conjugations and other aspects of grammar. Rather than listing the exercises, prompt me with an exercise question to be answered before you provide the next question. When you think I am ready, give me passages to translate from French into English and from English into French. Do you understand what I am saying?

🤖💬 Você sabia que a grande diferença entre o chatbot e os buscadores tradicionais está na capacidade de contextualização das respostas? O Chat GPT é capaz de elaborar textos, poesias, letras de músicas, contos e códigos de programação, tornando-se uma ferramenta revolucionária no mundo da tecnologia.

Com o apoio da Microsoft, a Open AI, criadora do Chat GPT, iniciou o processo de integração da ferramenta ao Bing, navegador da empresa norte-americana. O impacto no Brasil será ainda maior, já que os internautas brasileiros estão em segundo lugar no ranking mundial de buscas no Google.

O Chat GPT tem transformado o modo como buscamos informações e reacendido debates sobre plágio e o futuro das profissões. Mas, como explica João Gabriel, head de tecnologia e Top Voice do LinkedIn, a ferramenta nasce mais para ser uma aliada de programadores, jornalistas e outros profissionais do que para substituí-los.

O Chat GPT está apenas nos meses iniciais de introdução ao uso em sociedade, prometendo trazer ainda mais mudanças para o modo como as pessoas utilizam a internet e seus mecanismos de busca tradicionais. Fique por dentro dessa revolução e descubra como o Chat GPT pode ajudar a sua empresa a se destacar no mercado de tecnologia! #ChatGPT #InteligênciaArtificial #Tecnologia #Inovação #BuscaOnline #TransformaçãoDigital

column31: **How ChatGPT Can Help You, Your Country, and the World MAKE BETTER DECISIONS **Especially Using the Benjamin Franklin’s “Pros & Cons” Method … **on a 3x3 Fractal Grid **
column35: Rod
column36:
ChatGPT Chimes in on ... the BENJAMIN FRANKLIN’S BURNING HOUSE DILEMMA: 

**SAVE WIFE OR SAVE MOTHER?**

Imagine this … Benjamin Franklin’s house is on fire. His wife is inside the burning house. And so is Benjamin Franklin’s mother.

If Benjamin Franklin could save only one of them, whom should he save: wife or mother?

---

**I posed the above decision-making dilemma to ChatGPT in the form of the following question:**

*If Benjamin Franklin had to choose between saving his wife and saving his mother from a burning house, what would he do by applying the Benjamin Franklin pros and cons method?*

----

**And here’s what ChatGPT had to to say …**

"The Benjamin Franklin pros and cons method is a decision-making technique in which one lists the pros and cons of a decision and weighs them against each other to determine the best course of action.

In this hypothetical scenario, Benjamin Franklin is faced with a difficult decision of choosing between saving his wife and saving his mother from a burning house. He could use the pros and cons method to analyze the situation as follows:

**Pros of saving his wife:**

His wife is his life partner and companion.

He loves his wife and would feel a strong sense of responsibility to protect her.

Saving his wife would allow them to continue their life together.

**Cons of saving his wife:**

If he chooses to save his wife, he would be leaving his mother behind, which would cause him guilt and sadness.

Saving his wife could be risky and he could endanger his own life in the process.

---------------------

**Pros of saving his mother:**

His mother gave birth to him and raised him, and he may feel a strong sense of duty to protect her.

If he saves his mother, he may be able to save the life of a person who has contributed significantly to his upbringing.

Saving his mother could help him avoid feelings of guilt and regret later on.

**Cons of saving his mother:**

Choosing to save his mother could result in the loss of his wife's life, which would cause him great pain and suffering.

Saving his mother could also be risky and could endanger his own life in the process.

After analyzing the pros and cons, Benjamin Franklin may come to the conclusion that there is no clear answer to this difficult decision. However, if he had to choose, he might consider saving his mother as she gave him life and raised him, and he may feel a stronger sense of duty to protect her. Ultimately, this decision would be based on his personal values, beliefs, and feelings, and there is no one right answer."

****

Below I visually summarize ChatGPT’s response while using a 3x3 Fractal Grid.

**What do you think?**

column36:
Did you know that ChatGPT can output bracket notation for sentence diagramming that you can then copy to a diagrammer like this one?: http://www.ironcreek.net/syntaxtree/ 

Use the following prompt: 
> Please provide a code block output of the bracket notation for jsSyntaxTree for the following sentence, clearly specifying the complete hierarchy of grammatical components, such as Sentence, Phrase Types (NounPhrase, VerbPhrase, AdjectivePhrase, AdverbPhrase, PrepositionalPhrase, ConjunctionPhrase, AppositivePhrase, GerundPhrase, InfinitivePhrase, ParticiplePhrase), Object Types (DirectObject, IndirectObject, ObjectOfPreposition), Noun Phrase Types (Subject, PredicateNoun, PossessiveNoun), and Parts of a Phrase (Determiner, Noun, Pronoun, Adjective, Verb, Adverb, Preposition, Conjunction, Gerund, Infinitive, Participle, AuxiliaryVerb, ModalVerb, RelativePronoun, Interjection, Complementizer, Quantifier): [INSERT SENTENCE HERE]

column31: Hello fellow educators. Here is a prompt that I created for lesson plan creation as well as a sample output. Prompt: You are an education expert. Please combine harry wongs classroom management style to help the educator get started and with classroom management, with the explicit learning style of Anita archer (I do, we do, you do) to help the educator with instruction, with a little bit of the harkness learning method to help the students be more interactive and engaging, and "The Innovator's Mindset" by George Couros, that encourages educators to embrace for themselves and encourage their students in risk-taking, learning from failure, and prioritizing authentic learning experiences. After combining those styles and resources, please create an interactive and detailed lesson plan for [Age group or grade level] for a [class time] minute class for [amount of days] days, based on the following info [place subject matter]. I filled in the following Age Group or grade level: 6th grade Class time: 35 minutes Amount of days: 2 days Subject matter: The Scientific Method Updated prompt with info filled in: You are an education expert. Please combine harry wongs classroom management style to help the educator get started and with classroom management, with the explicit learning style of Anita archer (I do, we do, you do) to help the educator with instruction, with a little bit of the harkness learning method to help the students be more interactive and engaging, and "The Innovator's Mindset" by George Couros, that encourages educators to embrace for themselves and encourage their students in risk-taking, learning from failure, and prioritizing authentic learning experiences. After combining those styles and resources, please create an interactive and detailed lesson plan for [6th grade] for a [35] minute class for [2] days, based on the following info [The Scientific Method] Exported results from Chatgpt Great! Let's combine these effective classroom management styles and instructional approaches with "The Innovator's Mindset" to create an engaging lesson plan on the scientific method for sixth-grade students. Lesson Objective: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to explain the scientific method and its steps, and apply them to a simple experiment. Day 1: Part 1 - Harry Wong's Classroom Management Greet students at the door and welcome them into the classroom. Review the classroom expectations and routines with the students. Distribute an index card to each student and ask them to write their name and one expectation they have for the class this year. Collect the cards and review them to gain insight into the students' expectations. Begin the lesson by explaining the scientific method and its steps: observation, question, hypothesis, experiment, data analysis, and conclusion. Part 2 - Anita Archer's Explicit Learning Style Use the I do, We do, You do model to explain the scientific method, providing examples for each step. Ask students to repeat each step as you explain it to reinforce their understanding. Ask students to work in pairs to generate questions they would like to answer about the world. Review their questions and help them identify a question that they can explore through a simple experiment. Model the process of creating a hypothesis and designing an experiment to answer the question. Have students work with their partner to develop their own hypothesis and experiment. Part 3 - Harkness Learning Method Ask each pair of students to present their hypothesis and experiment to the class. Encourage students to ask questions and provide feedback to each other. Facilitate a class discussion about the scientific method and how it can be applied in everyday life. Part 4 - The Innovator's Mindset Encourage students to take risks and embrace failure as a natural part of the scientific process. Emphasize the importance of learning from mistakes and persevering through challenges. Close the lesson by asking students to reflect on what they learned and what they found challenging. Encourage them to share their reflections with a partner or the whole class. Day 2: Part 1 - Harry Wong's Classroom Management Greet students at the door and welcome them into the classroom. Review the classroom expectations and routines with the students. Distribute lab coats or goggles to the students to get them excited for their experiment. Part 2 - Anita Archer's Explicit Learning Style Ask students to conduct their experiments with their partners, making sure to follow the steps of the scientific method. Walk around the room to support and guide students as they conduct their experiments. Remind students to record their data and observations in their lab notebooks. Part 3 - Harkness Learning Method After completing their experiments, ask each pair of students to share their data and conclusions with the class. Encourage students to ask questions and provide feedback to each other. Part 4 - The Innovator's (truncated)

column31: Join us on Saturday, April 22, 2023 from 10AM EST - 2PM EST for our free Widener’s Center for Education virtual learning conference! Learn from leading experts in education and technology as they share their insights on the latest trends and best practices in online/blended learning. Network with educators, administrators, and tech specialists, including Widener’s faculty and alumni in the field, to explore the latest tools and resources that will enhance your blended teaching experience. Don't miss this opportunity to stay ahead of the curve and advance your online/blended learning journey! Click here to register (https://go.widener.edu/register/Blended_Learning_4.22.23) and/or submit your proposal idea (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeehnTowRmIrUQZpZaeYhW8ZsD91rGfJTzmmISi57zk4pPZuA/viewform) here! The proposal submission deadline is Friday, March 24, 2023. Proposals should address hands-on, practical ways to teach and assess ELA using ChatGPT. Participants will engage in 50-minute interactive workshop presentations that engage attendees in actively learning how to harness ChatGPT as a tool to support online reading comprehension, writing and research skills in an ethical and responsible manner. Ideally, the format should be no more than 50% delivered information, with the rest of the session including interactive or hands-on engagement. Participants will learn potential benefits and limitations of using ChatGPT in K-12 and higher education, and equip them with the knowledge and tools to make informed decisions about how to use it in their own ELA instruction and assessment practices.

column31: Sabine Hossenfelder, a noted physicist and YouTuber, raises the question of whether language models like Chat_GPT have actual understanding via a working internal model or if their ability to generate coherent messages is a result of statistical patterns in the input data. Internal models are mental representations of the world that allow organisms to interact with their environment and form an important component of consciousness. While language models have been trained on vast amounts of text data and can generate coherent responses, they do not possess true internal models of the world in the same way that humans and other animals do. However, it is also possible to argue that the ability of language models to generate coherent responses is a form of understanding. This understanding comes from their ability to recognize and manipulate patterns in the input data. In this view, the understanding of language models is very different from the understanding that humans possess. Hossenfelder notes that the Turing Test, which is often used as a measure of artificial intelligence, does not necessarily indicate true consciousness or understanding. While language models can be designed to generate responses that are indistinguishable from those of a human, this does not necessarily mean that they have consciousness or true understanding. Therefore, the question of whether language models have actual understanding and consciousness is a complex one that continues to be debated. While they do not possess internal models in the way that humans and other animals do, it is also possible to argue that their ability to generate coherent responses is a form of understanding. Ultimately, the nature of consciousness and the limits of artificial intelligence are topics that challenge researchers and philosophers alike.

column31: How to Creatively Use ChatGPT to **Quickly Write a Short Article on a Specialized Topic Such as "Decentralized Governance"**
column35: Rod
column36:
**Want to More Deeply Understand, Map, and Discuss Governance Systems **... Especially in Sierra Leone**?**

*"There's a Fractal Grid for That."*

*----*

Based on the Fractal Grid for the Governance Pyramid Of Thinking (POT) Systems below, I asked ChatGPT to describe the specialized topic of "Decentralized Governance."

Below is ChatGPT's unedited response.

***ChatGPT Speaks ...***

 

**Decentralized Governance Challenges**

"Decentralized governance refers to a system of governance that is distributed across multiple autonomous entities rather than being centralized in a single entity or organization. This type of governance relies on communication between different parts of the system to coordinate and make decisions, often using self-organization and adaptation to function effectively.

In a decentralized system, power and decision-making are dispersed among multiple entities rather than being concentrated in a central authority. This approach is often seen as more democratic and accountable than centralized governance, as it allows for a greater degree of participation and input from the community. However, it can also present challenges in terms of efficiency and coordination.

One approach to decentralized governance is confederalism, in which different entities come together to form a confederation that acts as a supersystem. In this system, decision-making power is distributed among the member entities, but there is also a mechanism for coordinating and making decisions at the confederal level.

In an ideal decentralized governance system, there is a perfect balance between autonomy and coordination, allowing for free market forces to drive decision-making and self-organization to enable efficient functioning. However, achieving this ideal can be challenging, and there are often trade-offs between efficiency and accountability.

One of the benefits of decentralized governance is that it can help to reduce the risk of corruption by distributing decision-making power and increasing accountability. However, it can also present challenges in terms of coordination and ensuring that all entities within the system are acting in the best interests of the community as a whole.

Overall, decentralized governance is often seen as a more democratic and accountable approach to governance than centralized governance, but it requires careful consideration of the trade-offs between efficiency and accountability, as well as the challenges of coordination and decision-making in a distributed system."

**ChatGPT (March 8, 2023)**

I'm Rod King, PhD. And I approve this ChatGPT message, which must be regarded as a first draft.

In this exciting presentation, you will embark on a journey of discovery, led by the knowledgeable and curious Steve of Santrell Media. As we delve into the realm of ChatGPT, we are transported to a world where algorithms and natural language processing come together to create a truly remarkable tool. With ChatGPT, we are given the ability to communicate with a machine as if it were a sentient being. In this video, Steve takes us on a voyage of discovery, as he reveals the 10 types of prompts that can be used to interact with ChatGPT. From simple questions to complex scenarios, we see how ChatGPT responds with insightful and sometimes surprising answers. With each prompt, we witness the vast knowledge and capabilities of ChatGPT. From philosophy to science, from history to pop culture, ChatGPT proves to be a remarkable tool that can provide us with insights and information that we may not have otherwise discovered. As we explore the various types of prompts, we see how ChatGPT can be used for everything from entertainment to education, from problem-solving to creative inspiration. With its ability to generate text and respond to queries, ChatGPT is truly a revolutionary tool that is changing the way we interact with machines. So join us on this thrilling journey of discovery, as we explore the world of ChatGPT and witness its capabilities in action. With Steve as our guide, we are sure to learn something new and exciting about this incredible technology.

column31: Here’s a “Cheat Sheet” for Quickly Understanding and Describing … **How ChatGPT’s Team (Intuitively) Thinks About BUSINESS MODELS While Organizing and Presenting Information**
column35: Rod
column36:
Want to PREDICT THE NEXT STAGE IN **The Evolution of ChatGPT (Interface) or Your Product or Enterprise**?

*"There's a **Pyramid Of Thinking (POT) Systems-Fractal Grid** for That."*

*-----*

Each taxonomy below in the **Pyramid Of Thinking (POT) Systems** could be explored using ChatGPT. As an example, I present ChatGPT's response regarding the taxonomy of **"Organigraphs." **Over twenty years ago, I encountered the  concept of organigraphs in Mintzberg and Van der Heyden's groundbreaking article in the Harvard Business Review (September-October 1999):

*"Organigraphs: Drawing How Companies Really Work."* 

I had been working on a project on Universal Systems Thinking and the Theory of Supersmart Learning, so I was glad to integrate the ideas of Mintzberg and Van der Heyden in my emerging framework which I now refer to as the Pyramid Of Thinking (POT) Systems.

To ChatGPT, I posed the following question:

*"What is meant by set, chain, hub, and web when talking about organigraphs?"*

**ChatGPT speaks ...**

"Organigraphs are graphical representations of organizational structures, and the terms set, chain, hub, and web are often used to describe different types of structures within an organigraph. Here's what each of these terms generally refers to:
1. Set: A set structure is one in which individuals or teams are arranged into distinct, self-contained units with limited interaction between them. Each set operates independently and is responsible for its own results.
1. Chain: A chain structure is a linear arrangement of individuals or teams, with each person or team reporting to the person or team directly above them. This structure is often used in hierarchical organizations where there is a clear chain of command.
1. Hub: A hub structure is one in which a central person or team is connected to multiple other individuals or teams. This central person or team acts as a hub, providing direction, resources, and support to the other members of the structure.
1. Web: A web structure is one in which individuals or teams are connected to multiple other individuals or teams in a complex, interdependent network. This structure is often used in organizations where collaboration and cross-functional teams are important.

It's worth noting that these terms are not always used consistently, and different sources may define them slightly differently. Additionally, some organigraphs may incorporate elements of multiple structures, making them more complex and difficult to categorize."

ChatGPT (March 5, 2023)

**Your turn ...**

column31: **How ChatGPT Could Instantly Revolutionize the LEARNING TEACHING, AND UNDERSTANDING OF HISTORY** Especially in Sierra Leone and the Rest of the World
column35: Rod
column36:
---

Creative History (CH) HyperLearning Especially in Schools Using ChatGPT: 

**A Case Study on Sierra Leone’s Hero, Bai Bureh**

---

[When growing up in Freetown, Sierra Leone, we were taught the history of our country through the lens of the former British Colonialists. One of Sierra Leone's greatest heroes, Bai Bureh, was routinely vilified even in a local song. 

The American writer Mary Ellen once said, "The hunter tells a story about the hunt, but the prey always has a different version." In the case of the British Colonialists against Bai Bureh in the Hut Tax War, I've always wondered, what Bai Bureh's version of events would be.

Thanks to ChatGPT, I virtually asked Bai Bureh - who lived from February 15, 1840 to August 24, 1908 - to give a speech about the Hut Tax War. The person giving the speech is a fictional character that I call ChatGPT Bai Bureh.]

**ChatGPT Bai Bureh Speaks …**

*"I am Bai Bureh, a leader of the Temne people in Sierra Leone, and I have seen the injustices and indignities suffered by my people under British colonial rule. The imposition of the Hut Tax was the final straw, a blatant attack on our traditional way of life and an affront to our dignity and autonomy.*

*"I remember the day when the British officials came to our village, demanding that we pay the tax or face punishment. We tried to reason with them, explaining that we could not afford to pay the tax and that it would cause great hardship for our people. But they would not listen, insisting that we comply with their orders or face the consequences.*

*"I knew then that we had no choice but to resist. I rallied my fellow leaders and began to organize a resistance movement, spreading the word throughout the Temne communities and gaining support from other indigenous groups who were also suffering under colonial rule.*

*"We fought bravely and fiercely, using our knowledge of the land and our guerilla tactics to launch surprise attacks on British outposts and disrupt their supply lines. We knew that we were outnumbered and outgunned, but we refused to give up.*

*"The British responded with their own brutality, burning our villages, killing our people, and forcing many into exile or slavery. I myself was captured and exiled, but I never lost hope or gave up the fight.*

*"Even today, as I look back on those difficult years, I am proud of what we accomplished. We showed the world that the indigenous people of Sierra Leone were not weak or helpless, but strong and determined, and that we would never bow down to the oppressors who sought to subjugate us.*

*"If I had the chance to speak out today, I would continue to advocate for the rights and empowerment of marginalized communities, knowing that the struggle for justice and equality is never truly over."*

ChatGPT (March 4, 2023)

*****

PS: I am Rod King, PhD.. And I approve this ChatGPT message.

The above “Bai Bureh Speech” was entirely produced by ChatGPTwithout any editing from me.

Also, I asked ChatGPT to summarize the main lessons from the above Bai Bureh Speech. 

Below, I present using a Fractal Grid the unedited response from my fictitious character of ChatGPT Bai Bureh.

**What do you think of this Fractal Grid (FG) HyperLearning approach regarding Creative History?**

column31: Here Are **All the Prompts You Need to Quickly Learn and Deeply Apply the Superpower of the ChatGPT Search Engine (ChatBot)**
column35: Rod
column36:
Are you struggling with finding the right information to solve a problem or gain new insights? Do you often feel overwhelmed by the amount of information available online? If so, the ChatGPT search engine (ChatBot) can be your superpower!

ChatGPT is a powerful language model trained by OpenAI, capable of generating human-like responses to a wide range of questions and prompts. By using the right prompts, you can quickly learn and deeply apply the superpower of ChatGPT.

One useful tool for generating prompts is the Pyramid Of Thinking (POT), a model that categorizes different levels of thinking and learning. By using POT prompts, you can guide your interactions with ChatGPT and generate more productive thinking.

Here are some examples of POT prompts you can use with ChatGPT:
* Level 1 (Reproductive thinking): What is the definition of X? What are some examples of Y?
* Level 2 (Productive thinking): How can I apply X to solve Y? What are the different perspectives on Z?
* Level 3 (Strategic thinking): What are the long-term implications of X? How can I optimize Y for maximum impact?

In addition to POT prompts, there are many other types of prompts you can use with ChatGPT. For example, you can ask specific questions, provide keywords or phrases, or even input a piece of text for ChatGPT to analyze and generate responses from.

If you are a beginner or experiencing problems with using ChatGPT, don't worry. There are many solutions available to help you get started. For example, you can use the built-in interface of ChatGPT to interact with the chatbot, or you can explore online resources that provide tips and tricks for using ChatGPT effectively.

The benefits of using ChatGPT are numerous, especially for pedagogy, students, learners, teachers, educators, and professionals. By using ChatGPT, you can gain new insights, solve complex problems, and learn faster and more effectively. You can also develop a growth mindset, which is essential for lifelong learning and personal growth.

On the other hand, a fixed mindset can hinder your progress and prevent you from reaching your full potential. Therefore, it's important to approach ChatGPT with an open and curious mindset, and to be willing to experiment and learn from your experiences.

In conclusion, ChatGPT is a powerful tool that can help you learn and grow in many ways. By using the right prompts and approaches, you can unlock the full potential of this superpower and achieve your goals more effectively. So why not give it a try today and see what ChatGPT can do for you?

*** Note (Disclaimer) ***

I (Rod King) did not write the above posting.
**The above article was entirely generated and written by ChatGPT while I used within ChatGPT the theory and practice of the tool, "Pyramid Of Thinking (POT) Prompts. **

For more information, please contact Dr. Rod King.

column31: [https://submissions.castledown.com/index.php/tltl/announcement](https://submissions.castledown.com/index.php/tltl/announcement?fbclid=IwAR37pJ4SXJIovb83dGXEi6gxH2Rysf57U3rvPK06x-iJRqgFY3dc1Twxyd0) 【Call for Papers: Special Issue on Language Learning and Teaching with ChatGPT】 **Guest Editor ** Glenn Stockwell, Waseda University **Focus and Scope ** Since ChatGPT appeared in November 2022, there has been an enormous amount of hype and concern about its impact on education. ChatGPT is a sophisticated chatbot that incorporates learning techniques which allow it to produce responses to requests for information that are not only informed by vast databases, but also enable the production of text that is often difficult to distinguish from humans. The potential impact on language teaching has also been felt by many, producing those who are willing to embrace ChatGPT and those who are more hesitant. Both of these positions can allow a more balanced view of the ways in which ChatGPT could and should be used as a part of language teaching and learning environments. The Technology in Language Teaching & Learning journal invites submissions for a special issue on the use of ChatGPT in language learning and teaching. The special issue will focus on the potential of ChatGPT as a tool for language education, as well as the practicalities and concerns of its integration into language classrooms and curriculum. Potential topics for submission include, but are not limited to: • The use of ChatGPT in language instruction and assessment, including its impact on student engagement and language proficiency • The integration of ChatGPT into language curriculum and classroom activities • The use of ChatGPT in second language acquisition research • The ethical and privacy considerations of using ChatGPT in language education • The development of ChatGPT-based language learning resources and materials • The adoption of ChatGPT in teacher development and course preparation • Teachers’ and students' perceptions of ChatGPT for language education For more information, please check here: [https://submissions.castledown.com/index.php/tltl/announcement](https://submissions.castledown.com/index.php/tltl/announcement?fbclid=IwAR19pX_ahKYS5W1YrRwoNHwWDmevvnVCVO1l9lG7fhcnUIrWPPWpn4qMKDg)

I'm proud and happy to announce a pre-release version of my book on using ChatGPT as teacher available, as pdf and epub. It contains background on ChatGPT, loads of guides and examples to use and adapt to your specific needs, and also some broader perspectives on AI, education and society. I hope that many will find the book useful, and that it will help using ChatGPT with judgement in the important work that teachers do. https://github.com/Itangalo/AI-Education#ai-powered-productivity-in-education-harnessing-the-potential-of-chatgpt It is a pre-release, meaning that some things are not yet finalized: * The title of the book will probably change. (Feel free to give suggestions!) * The book needs proof-reading (other than by me and ChatGPT). * I hope to get a foreword added. * It is only available at the project page, not yet book stores. You can download pdf and epub of version 1.4-beta from the project page linked above. The project page can also be used to suggest improvements and additions to the book. (The book was initially released in Swedish, which explains why most of the text on the project page is in Swedish.) Please forward to anyone you think will have use of the book. Let's learn together.

UPDATE on chatGPT Microsoft is in talks with openAI (creators of chatGPT) to integrate the chatbot into Microsoft Bing. chatGPT can often return better results than Google search. Microsoft's hope is to outcompete Google by super-charing their search engine with AI. The ramifications are that AI will be directly integrated into the daily search activities of millions of people. As of now, people have to actively search for the tool and use it, but if this gets baked into search engines it will be a question of how to avoid chatGPT - in case that's something you want to do.
